definition: A designated area where unused quantities of water or fire retardant may be jettisoned, usually to permit an airtanker to land with less than a full load.
label: abort area

definition: Term frequently used in aviation operations, usually in connection with a stated altitude.
label: Above Ground Level

definition: According to the American Meteorological Society, (also called vapor density).  In a system of moist air, the ratio of the mass of water vapor present to the volume occupied by the mixture; that is, the density of the water vapor component.
label: absolute humidity

definition: The act of controlling hazardous spilled or leaking materials.
label: containment (hazardous materials)

definition: The status of a wildfire suppression action signifying that a control line has been completed around the fire, and any associated spot fires, which can reasonably be expected to stop the fire's spread.
label: contained
editorial note: JK-checked.  Related terms exceed those listed in NWCG.
related term: containment (wildfire), containment (hazardous materials), point/zone protection, confine

definition: A wildfire response strategy which protects specific assets or highly valued resources from the wildfire without directly halting the continued spread of the wildfire.
label: point/zone protection
definition extension:
1. Points or zones being protected may be communities, individual structures, areas of high resource value, etc.
  2. Continued wildfire spread may be desirable in order to achieve management objectives or may be inevitable due to extreme burning conditions, safety concerns, or other limitations.

definition: A fire in which a solid flame develops in the crowns of trees, but the surface and crown phases advance as a linked unit dependent on each other.
label: active crown fire

definition: The accelerated spreading of a fire with time.
label: build-up (fire spread)

definition: The cumulative effects of long-term drying on current fire danger.
label: build-up (fire danger)

definition: The building block of foam; bubble characteristics of water content and durability influence foam performance.
label: bubble

definition: Any light, mobile vehicular unit with limited pumping and water capacity for off-road operations.
label: brush patrol unit

definition: Application of herbicide to desiccate living vegetation prior to burning.
label: brown and burn

definition: Means "turn" left or right. Applies to aircraft in flight, usually on the drop run, and when given as a command to the pilot, implies expectation of prompt compliance.
label: break left or right

definition: To insert a gate valve or some other device into a hose line.
label: break a line

definition: The organizational level having functional or geographical responsibility for major parts of incident operations. The branch level is organizationally between section and division/group in the operations section, and between section and unit in the logistics section. Branches are identified by roman numerals or by functional name (e.g. service, support).
label: branch

definition: A steep-sided, dead end canyon.
label: box canyon

definition: According to the American Meteorological Society, the layer of air near a boundary that is affected by friction against that boundary surface, and possibly by transport of heat and other variables across that surface.
label: boundary layer (air)

definition: A reel for the booster hose mounted on a fire engine, often supplied by the auxiliary pump. This reel usually carries a 1-inch (25 mm) or 3/4 inch (19 mm) hose and frequently contains an electric rewind mechanism.
label: booster reel

definition: An area cleared to mineral soil for piling unburned fuels.
label: bone yard (area)

definition: The trunk of a tree.
label: bole

definition: A ceiling of less than 3,000 feet (900 m) which rapidly increases or decreases in height by one or more reportable values during the period of observation.
label: variable ceiling

definition: The term for horizontal air currents merging together or approaching a single point, such as at the center of a low pressure area producing a net inflow of air. When this occurs in the lower atmosphere, the excess air is removed by rising air currents. Expansion of the rising air above a convergence zone results in cooling, which in turn often gives condensation (clouds) and sometimes precipitation.
label: convergence

definition: Rate of heat release per unit of burning area per unit of time.
label: combustion rate

definition: Air which has assumed high moisture content and the temperature characteristics of a water surface due to extensive exposure to that surface.
label: maritime air

definition: Layer of clouds whose ratio of dense sky cover to total sky cover is 1/2 or less.
label: thin layer

definition: A circular-like flow of a fluid (such as air or water) drawing its energy from a flow of much larger scale, and brought about by pressure irregularities as in the downwind (lee) side of a solid obstacle. For example, wind conditions may be erratic and may eddy on the downwind side of large rock outcroppings, buildings, etc.
label: eddy

definition: A sampling of upper air conditions made by means of instruments and a small radio transmitter on a free balloon. Automatic radio signals originated by action of weather instruments are sent to a ground receiver. These signals are interpreted for use in analyzing and predicting upper air conditions over a wide area of the earth. Weather elements determined at a number of altitude points as the balloon rises are temperature, atmospheric moisture, pressure, wind direction and speed. Similar soundings may be made using fixed balloons or tethersondes.
label: sounding (upper air sounding)

definition: Winds which are generated over a comparatively small area by local terrain and weather. They differ from those which would be appropriate to the general pressure pattern.
label: local winds

definition: Precipitation falling out of a cloud but evaporating before reaching the ground.
label: virga

definition: A capability through the use of a special mobile ground station to receive air-to-ground IR imagery at an incident.
label: Infrared Groundlink

definition: A quantitative measure of fuel moisture and receptability to ignition as determined by an accepted Fire Danger Rating System index that influences fire growth, intensity, or activity.
label: Fuel Dryness Level
related term: Dry Episode, high fire risk day

definition: Rapid combustion and/or explosion of unburned gases trapped at some distance from the main fire front. Usually occurs only in poorly ventilated topography.
label: flashover (behavior)

definition: A number representing the net effect of evaporation, transpiration and precipitation in producing cumulative moisture depletion in deep duff or upper soil layers.
label: drought index

definition: The decrease in concentration of airborne pollutants as they spread throughout an increasing volume of atmosphere.
label: dispersion

definition: A numerical value relating the potential of the atmosphere to disperse airborne pollutants from a stationary source, calculated by multiplying the mixing height by the transport wind speed.
label: ventilation factor

definition: The display or printout of an infrared scanner operating over a fire.
label: thermal imagery

definition: A breeze (wind) blowing inland from the sea generally during daytime hours.
label: sea breeze

definition: The mean solar times of sunset and sunrise as published in the Nautical Almanac, converted to local standard time for the locality concerned.
label: sunset and sunrise

definition: The number that results from manipulating raw data according to a specified procedure; associated with samples.
label: statistic

definition: An elongated area of relatively high atmospheric pressure extending from the center of a high-pressure region.
label: ridge

definition: Likelihood that a wildfire capable of causing considerable damage will occur.
label: conflagration threat

definition: The computed total heat release per unit area (British thermal units per square foot) within the flaming front at the head of a moving fire.
label: Energy Release Component

definition: Any or all forms of water particles, liquid or solid, that fall from the atmosphere and reach the ground.
label: precipitation

definition: Carbon dust formed by incomplete combustion.
label: soot

definition: A forecast of the probability of occurrence of one or more of a mutually exclusive set of weather contingencies as distinguished from a series of categorical statements.
label: probability forecast

definition: Total amount of heat produced per unit mass of fuel consumed per unit time.
label: heat release rate (consumed)

definition: Sudden increase in fireline intensity or rate of spread of a fire sufficient to preclude direct control or to upset existing suppression plans. Often accompanied by violent convection and may have other characteristics of a fire storm.
label: blowup
related term: flare-up, extreme fire behavior, fire storm

definition: Stage of a fire at which all surfaces and objects within a space have been heated to their ignition temperature, and flame breaks out almost at once over the surface of all objects within the space.
label: flashover (stage of fire)

definition: The greatly increased rate of water run off and soil movement from steep slopes that may follow removal of the vegetative cover by burning.
label: fire-flood cycle

definition: Atmospheric inversion. The departure from the usual increase or decrease with altitude of the value of an atmospheric property. In fire management usage, nearly always refers to an increase in temperature with increasing height. Also, the layer through which this departure occurs (also called inversion layer.) The lowest altitude at which the departure is found is called the base of the inversion.
label: inversion
related term: stable layer of air, atmospheric inversion, atmospheric stability

definition: According to the American Meteorological Society, a departure from the usual decrease or increase with altitude of the value of an atmospheric property; also, the layer through which this departure occurs (the "inversion layer"), or the lowest altitude at which the departure is found ("the base of the inversion"). In fire management usage, nearly always refers to an increase in temperature with increasing height.
label: atmospheric inversion
related term: inversion, stable layer of air, atmospheric stability

definition: A chart of wind speed in relation to height, most commonly determined by a pilot balloon observation.
label: wind profile

definition: In fire weather, that area where two winds come together from opposite directions and are forced upwards often creating clouds and precipitation.
label: convergence zone (fire weather)

definition: A handheld device which indicates wind speed, usually in miles per hour.
label: windspeed meter

definition: A public information description of the relative severity of the current fire danger situation.
label: adjective rating

definition: An area on the earth's surface where atmospheric pressure is at a relative minimum. Winds blow counter-clockwise around lows in the Northern Hemisphere but, due to friction with the earth's surface, tend to cross constant pressure lines toward the low center. Upon converging into the low's center, air currents are forced to rise. As air rises it cools due to expansion. Cooling reduces its capacity to hold moisture; so cloudiness and precipitation are common in lows. If a low center intensifies sufficiently it will take on the characteristics of a storm center with precipitation and strong winds.
label: surface low

definition: Wind measured at a surface observing station, customarily at some distance (usually 20 feet) above the average vegetative surface to minimize the distorting effects of local obstacles and terrain.
label: surface wind

definition: According to the American Meteorological Society, same as centigrade temperature scale, by convention. Centigrade temperature scale is a temperature scale with the ice point of water at 0 degrees and the boiling point at 100 degrees.
label: celsius

definition: A sky condition that varies between reportable values of sky cover amounts during the period of observation.
label: variable sky condition

definition: Condition of the atmosphere in which the temperature decrease with increasing altitude is less than the dry adiabatic lapse rate. In this condition, the atmosphere tends to suppress large-scale vertical motion.
label: stable atmosphere

definition: According to the American Meteorological Society, the ability of the atmosphere at rest to become turbulent or laminar due to the effects of buoyancy. Air tending to become or remain turbulent is said to be statically unstable; one tending to become or remain laminar is statically stable; and one on the borderline between the two (which might remain laminar or turbulent depending on its history) is statically neutral.
label: atmospheric stability
related term: inversion, stable layer of air, atmospheric inversion

definition: In a psychrometer, the thermometer with its bulb covered with a jacket of clean muslin which is saturated with distilled water before an observation.
label: wet-bulb thermometer

definition: An area of relatively low atmospheric pressure in which winds tend to move in a counterclockwise direction, spiraling in toward the low's center.
label: low

definition: The transfer of heat by the movement of a gas or liquid; convection, conduction, and radiation are the principal means of energy transfer.
label: convection (energy transfer)

definition: A measure of the volume rate of horizontal transport of air within the mixing layer, per unit distance, normal to the wind. Units are measured in square meters per second or knot-feet.
label: ventilation index

definition: That portion of the atmosphere from the surface up to the mixing height. This is the layer of air, usually below a stable layer, within which pollutants are mixed by turbulence and diffusion.
label: mixing layer

definition: A weather station that transmits weather observations via GOES satellite to the Wildland Fire Management Information system.
label: Remote Automatic Weather Station

definition: Sky cover through which higher clouds or the sky can be detected.
label: thin sky cover

definition: Amount of heat released to the atmosphere from the convective-lift fire phase of a fire per unit time.
label: heat release rate (released)

definition: Mobile weather monitoring station. Each unit consists of a shipping container, solar panel, battery, temperature/relative humidity sensor, wind mast, wind direction/speed sensor, data logger and radio. A Micro-REMS usually accompanies an incident meteorologist and ATMU to an incident.
label: Micro-Remote Environmental Monitoring System

definition: A Fire Weather Watch is issued to advise of conditions which could result in extensive wildland fire occurrence or extreme fire behavior, which are expected to develop in the next 12 to 48 hours, but not more than 72 hours. In cases of dry lightning, a Fire Weather Watch may be issued for the next 12 hours.
label: fire weather watch

definition: Wind speed less than 7 mph (6 knots) measured at 20 feet above ground. At eye level, light winds are less than 3 mph (3 knots).
label: light wind

definition: A portion of the general fire weather forecast issued on a regular basis during the normal fire season specifically to fit the requirements of fire management needs; i.e., time, areas, and weather elements. These zones or areas are a combination of administrative and climatological areas, usually nearly the size of an individual forest or district.
label: zone weather forecast

definition: Wind blowing from land to water.
label: offshore flow

definition: Highly combustible fine fuels such as grass, leaves, draped pine needles, fern, tree moss and some kinds of slash, which ignite readily and are consumed rapidly when dry.
label: flash fuels

definition: Change of an atmospheric variable (temperature unless specified otherwise) with height.
label: lapse rate

definition: A code which expresses the amount of cloud cover, kind of precipitation, and/or restrictions to visibility being observed at the fire danger station at basic observation time.
label: state of weather

definition: The greatest horizontal distance at which selected objects can be seen and identified, or its equivalent derived from instrumental measurements.
label: visibility

definition: A number representing the chance that a given event will occur. The range is from 0% for an impossible event, to 100% for an inevitable event.
label: probability

definition: Generally considered only photochemical air pollution. Originally meant a combination of smoke and fog.
label: smog

definition: According to the American Meteorological Society, the height ascribed to the lowest layer of clouds or obscuring phenomena when it is reported as broken, overcast, or obscuration and not classified "thin" or "partial." The ceiling is termed unlimited when the foregoing conditions are not satisfied.
label: ceiling

definition: The central point or area of a weather system associated with increased winds, clouds or precipitation (or any combination thereof).
label: storm center

definition: A weather phenomenon resulting in an environment that has a significant impact on fire spread, intensity, or occurrence. Example: strong wind, unstable air mass, etc.
label: significant weather trigger
related term: fire potential, high fire risk day

definition: Wind blowing from water to land.
label: onshore flow

definition: The time, in seconds, required for the flaming front of a fire to pass a stationary point at the surface of the fuel. The total length of time that the flaming front of the fire occupies one point.
label: residence time

definition: A day when an ignition trigger and/or significant weather trigger and an appropriate fuel dryness level combine to create conditions that historically have resulted in a significant fire event for a particular area.
label: high fire risk day
related term: ignition trigger, significant fire event, Fuel Dryness Level, significant weather trigger

definition: Small scale convective winds that occur due to local heating and cooling of a natural incline of the ground.
label: slope winds

definition: General term referring to the moisture content of the atmosphere.
label: humidity

definition: The leading edge of a relatively cold air mass which displaces warmer air, causing it to rise. If the lifted air contains enough moisture, cloudiness, precipitation and even thunderstorms may result. As fronts move through a region, in the Northern Hemisphere, the winds at a given location will experience a marked shift in direction. Ahead of an approaching cold front, winds will usually shift gradually from southeast to south, and on to southwest. As a cold front passes, winds shift rapidly to west, then northwest. Typical cold front windspeeds range between 15 and 30 mph but can be much higher.
label: cold front

definition: Wind, in miles per hour, measured at 20 feet above open, level ground or as adjusted to meet this standard to compensate for height of ground cover, uneven ground, and nearby obstructions.
label: wind speed (open ground)

definition: A simplified or generalized representation of reality; a description, analogy, picture, or hypothesis to help visualize something that cannot be directly observed.
label: model

definition: A Heat Low which is elongated in shape.
label: Heat Trough
alternative label: Thermal Low, Thermal Trough, Heat Low

definition: Wind direction which varies by 60 degrees or more during the period of time the wind direction is being determined.
label: variable wind direction

definition: An area on the earth's surface where atmospheric pressure is at a relative maximum. Winds blow clockwise around highs in the Northern Hemisphere but, due to friction with the earth's face, tend to cross constant pressure lines away from the high center. Air is usually subsiding above a surface high. This causes warming due to air compression. This results in stable atmospheric conditions and light surface winds.
label: surface high

definition: Downward or sinking motion of air in the atmosphere. Subsiding air warms due to compression. Increasing temperature and decreasing humidities are present in subsiding air. Subsidence results in a stable atmosphere inhibiting dispersion. Subsidence is generally associated with high atmospheric pressure.
label: subsidence

definition: A model that is a diagram or description of a set of relationships between factors that describe how a system works, such as an ecological model.
label: conceptual model

definition: The complex surroundings of an item or area of interest, such as air, water, natural resources, and their physical conditions (temperature, humidity).
label: environment

definition: Wind, in miles per hour,  measured at 20 feet above ground, or above the average height of vegetation, and averaged over at least a 10-minute period.
label: wind speed (velocity)

definition: Lightning in a long zigzag or apparently broken line.
label: chain lightning

definition: The number of items or observations in a sample; usually denoted by lower case letter n.
label: sample size

definition: A forecast, issued daily during the regular fire season to resource management agencies, that is intended for planning of daily fire management activities, including daily staffing levels, prevention programs, and initial attack on wildfires.
label: general fire weather forecast
related term: incident support organization, spot weather forecast, incident weather forecast

definition: Climate characterized by (a) a long winter-spring dry season which includes a "cold season" followed by a short "hot season" immediately preceding the rains, (b) a summer and early autumn rainy season which is usually very wet (but highly variable from year to year), and (c) a secondary maximum of temperature immediately after the rainy season.
label: monsoon climate

definition: Of, or pertaining to, measurement by weight.
label: gravimetric

definition: Time, in hours and fraction of hours, that a precipitation event lasts. More precisely, for fire danger rating purposes, the length of time that fuels are subjected to liquid water.
label: precipitation duration

definition: A heat detection system used for fire detection, mapping, and hotspot identification.
label: Infrared

definition: A weather system usually associated with clouds, rain and/or wind.
label: disturbance

definition: A layer of air having a temperature change (lapse rate) of less than dry adiabatic (approximately -5.4 degrees F per 1,000 feet) thereby retarding either upward or downward mixing of smoke.
label: stable layer of air

definition: The speed of the wind measured at the midpoint of the flames, considered to be most representative of the speed of the wind that is affecting fire behavior.
label: mid-flame windspeed

definition: Wildfire caused directly or indirectly by lightning.
label: lightning fire

definition: A special forecast issued to fit the time, topography, and weather of a specific incident. These forecasts are issued upon request of the user agency and are more detailed, timely, and specific than zone forecasts. Usually, on-site weather observations or a close, representative observation is required for a forecast to be issued.
label: spot weather forecast
related term: general fire weather forecast, incident support organization, incident weather forecast

definition: Thunderstorm in which negligible precipitation reaches the ground.
label: dry lightning storm

definition: An apparent force due to the rotation of the earth that causes a deflection of air to the right in the Northern Hemisphere and to the left in the Southern Hemisphere. This force maximizes at the poles and is essentially zero at the equator.
label: Coriolis Force

definition: Measured from the surface upward, the height to which relatively vigorous mixing occurs due to convection.
label: mixing height

definition: For aviation purposes, a change in the average wind direction of 45 degrees or more which takes place in less than 15 minutes if the wind speed during this period is 6 knots (3 m/s) or greater.
label: wind shift (aviation)

definition: The increase in fuel moisture as a result of increased relative humidity, usually occurring overnight.
label: recovery (increased relative humidity)

definition: A method of determining winds aloft by periodically reading the elevation and azimuth angles of a theodolite, usually at one-minute intervals, while tracking the ascent of a small free-lift balloon. A PIBAL is commonly used for constructing a wind profile.
label: Pilot Balloon Operation

definition: The distribution of surface atmospheric pressure features over an area of the earth as shown on a weather map. Surface pressure features include lines of constant pressure (isobars), highs, lows, and pressure gradient. The pressure pattern is directly related to wind speeds and directions at specific locations.
label: pressure pattern

definition: Regional climate under the predominant influence of the sea, that is, a climate characterized by marine air; the opposite of a continental climate.
label: marine climate

definition: A causative agent for wildland fire. For example, human or lightning.
label: ignition trigger
related term: fire potential, high fire risk day

definition: A device carried aloft by a balloon equipped with measuring instruments that automatically convert temperature, pressure, and humidity data into electrical impulses and transmit this information to a ground recorder.
label: radiosonde

definition: A portion of the atmosphere that has a relatively low dew point temperature and where the formation of clouds, fog, or precipitation is unlikely.
label: dry air mass

definition: The ratio between the surface area of an object, such as a fuel particle, to its volume. The smaller the particle, the more quickly it can become wet, dry out, or become heated to combustion temperature during a fire.
label: surface area-to-volume ratio

definition: In aviation forecasting, an expression of hazardous weather conditions not predicted in the zone weather forecast, as they affect the operation of air traffic.
label: weather advisory

definition: Period of the year that normally comprises the fire season based on historical fire occurrence.
label: normal fire season (period of time)

definition: An atmospheric index used to indicate the potential for wildfire growth by measuring the stability and dryness of the air over a fire.
label: Haines Index

definition: The difference in atmospheric pressure between two points on a weather map. That is, the magnitude of pressure difference between two points at sea level, or at constant elevation above sea level. Wind speed is directly related to pressure gradient. If distance between constant pressure lines is reduced by one-half, wind speed will be doubled. Conversely, if distance between lines is doubled, wind speed will be reduced by one-half.
label: pressure gradient

definition: An increase in the central pressure of a low. Counter-clockwise wind flow around the low usually decreases as filling occurs.
label: filling

definition: The ratio of the amount of moisture in the air, to the maximum amount of moisture that air would contain if it were saturated. The ratio of the actual vapor pressure to the saturated vapor pressure.
label: Relative Humidity

definition: Towering cumulus clouds which may lead to thunderstorms later in the day.
label: build-up (weather)
editorial note: JK-checked.  FDS and IOSC also listed in NWCG.

definition: A random exchange of air parcels on any scale from the molecular to the largest eddy.
label: mixing

definition: The rising column of gases, smoke, fly ash, particulates, and other debris produced by a fire. The column has a strong vertical component indicating that buoyant forces override the ambient surface wind.
label: convection column
editorial note: JK-checked.  Related term "Plume" is not listed in NWCG.

definition: A model that is a quantitative and mathematical representation or simulation which attempts to describe the characteristics or relationship of physical events.
label: mathematical model

definition: The rate of heat release, per unit area of the flaming fire front, expressed as heat energy/area/time, such as Btu/square foot/minute, or Kcal/square meter/second.
label: reaction intensity

definition: A layer of clouds whose ratio of dense sky cover to total sky cover is more than one-half.
label: dense layer

definition: Condition in which temperature decrease with increasing altitude is equal to the dry adiabatic lapse rate (i.e., the atmosphere neither aids nor hinders large-scale vertical motion).
label: neutral atmosphere

definition: An event measured by the occurrence of fire(s) that requires mobilization of additional resources from outside the fire event area.
label: significant fire event
related term: Dry Episode, high fire risk day

definition: According to the American Meteorological Society, the general name for instruments designed to measure total wind speed.
label: anemometer

definition: Device commonly used to collect and permit measurement of any form of rain and snow sufficiently heavy to have fallen to the earth's surface.
label: precipitation gauge

definition: Geographical area for which a fire weather forecast is specified.
label: forecast area

definition: Set of computerized FIREMODELS run during fire season at the operations coordination center on preselected locations to indicate possible fire spread from those points for that date.
label: FIRECAST

definition: Term used by fire weather forecasters to alert forecast users to an ongoing or imminent critical fire weather pattern.
label: red flag warning

definition: In a psychrometer, the thermometer not covered with muslin which is used to determine air temperature.
label: dry-bulb thermometer

definition: The ultimate growth of a cumulus cloud into an anvil-shaped cloud with considerable vertical development, usually with fibrous ice crystal tops, and usually accompanied by lightning, thunder, hail, and strong winds.
label: cumulonimbus

definition: Graph showing the increase in temperature at a specified point in a fire as a function of time, beginning with ignition and ending with burnout.
label: time-temperature curve

definition: A contiguous series of days having a pre-established number of fire ignitions with a fuel dryness level that historically resulted in a significant fire event for a particular area.
label: Dry Episode
related term: significant fire event, Fuel Dryness Level

definition: Time of day required to record meteorological data at a fire danger station.
label: observation time

definition: According to the American Meteorological Society, the net force per unit area exerted by the atmosphere as a consequence of gravitational attraction exerted upon the column of air lying directly above the point in question.  Atmospheric pressure is independent of the orientation of the surface on which it acts.
label: atmospheric pressure

definition: A term used in weather primarily to describe a weak disturbance that does not necessarily have an associated storm center or surface low. The disturbance usually does not create severe weather and is frequently associated with a marine air push.
label: impulse

definition: Readily vaporized organic materials which, when mixed with oxygen, are easily ignited.
label: volatiles

definition: A line connecting points of equal temperature on a weather map.
label: isotherm

definition: Crystals of ice formed and deposited like dew, but at a temperature below freezing.
label: frost

definition: A measure of the average rate of the horizontal transport of air within the Mixing Layer. May also be the wind speed at the final height of plume rise. Generally refers to the rate at which emissions will be transported from one area to another.
label: transport wind speed

definition: Irregular motion of the atmosphere usually produced when air flows over a comparatively uneven surface such as the surface of the earth; or when two currents of air flow past or over each other in different directions or at different speeds.
label: turbulence

definition: Resistance to wetting exhibited by some soils, also called water repellency. The phenomenon may occur naturally or may be fire-induced. It may be determined by water drop penetration time, equilibrium liquid-contact angles, solid-air surface tension indices, or the characterization of dynamic wetting angles during infiltration.
label: hydrophobicity

definition: The difference between the wet and dry-bulb temperatures recorded by a psychrometer; used in conjunction with the dry-bulb temperature as a measure of the relative humidity of the air.
label: wet-bulb depression

definition: Large scale winds caused by high- and low-pressure systems but generally influenced and modified in the lower atmosphere by terrain.
label: general winds

definition: A fire weather fire danger product based on a thorough evaluation of all pertinent sources of meteorological, fire danger and resource information.
label: assessment (fire weather)

definition: The transformation of a liquid to its gaseous state; heat is released by the liquid during this process.
label: evaporation

definition: A special weather forecast for a specific incident prepared by a meteorologist on site at or near the incident area.
label: incident weather forecast
related term: general fire weather forecast, spot weather forecast

definition: According to the American Meteorological Society, a law describing the relationship of the horizontal wind direction in the atmosphere to the pressure distribution; if one stands with the back to the wind, the pressure to the left is lower than to the right in the Northern Hemisphere.
label: Buys Ballots Law

definition: The gases, smoke, and debris that rise slowly from a fire while being carried along the ground because the buoyant forces are exceeded by those of the ambient surface wind.
label: smoke plume

definition: Individual responsible to the Deck Coordinator for the manifesting, loading and unloading of personnel, equipment and cargo.
label: Loadmaster

definition: Airtanker drop in which tank doors are opened in sequence so that fire retardant cascades somewhat continuously.
label: incremental drop

definition: Connecting a (airtanker) drop to the forward part of a previous drop.
label: tag-on

definition: Standards of the National Fire Protection Association are frequently adopted by insurance agencies such as the National Board of Fire Underwriters as a basis for their regulations and used as a guide for municipal, state, or provincial laws, ordinances, and regulations.
label: National Fire Protection Association Standards

definition: Factors that make up fuels such as compactness, loading, horizontal continuity, vertical arrangement, chemical content, size and shape, and moisture content.
label: fuel characteristics

definition: In WIMS, a weather station that is no longer in service for which access to archived observations is still available in NIFMID.
label: historical weather station

definition: The implementation of a command decision to move a resource or resources from one place to another.
label: dispatch

definition: The residue of mineral matter left after complete combustion of wood (wood ash) or other organic material; consists largely of oxides, carbonates, and phosphates of Ca, K and Mg, together with other compounds.
label: mineral ash

definition: Derived from the incident position descriptions and are a component of NWCG standards. Position specific standards specify the tasks and behaviors that make up the incident position’s duties and responsibilities.
label: position specific standard

definition: Evaluation of all factors pertinent to probable future behavior of a going fire and of the potential ability of available forces to perform fire suppression operations on a specified time schedule.
label: calculation of probabilities

Glossary Term: fire pattern indicator, angle of scorch
definition: Scorch pattern left on canopy of standing fuels that indicates the direction of fire progression at that point. This fire pattern indicator is included within the fire pattern indicator category of Angle of Char.
label: fire pattern indicator, angle of scorch
alternative label: angle of scorch fire pattern indicator

definition: Relating to a harmful effect by a poisonous substance on the human body by physical contact, ingestion, or inhalation.
label: toxic

definition: To be on fire.
label: burn (on fire)

definition: An area in which neither the ground nor its vegetation can be seen from a given observation point.
label: blind area

definition: The time established to take the fire danger observations. It should be at the time of day when the fire danger is normally the highest. The usually agreed upon time is 1:00 pm standard time. This allows time to transmit observations and prepare forecasts.
label: base observation time
definition extension: Part of the National Fire Danger Rating System.

definition: Individuals within ICS organizational units who are responsible for recording information. Recorders may be found in planning, logistics and finance/administration units.
label: recorders

definition: A repair (1) that, if improperly done, might appreciably affect weight, balance, structural strength, or other qualities affecting airworthiness or (2) that is not done according to accepted practices or cannot be done by elementary operations.
label: major repair (aviation)

definition: A circular holding pattern of an aircraft around a fixed location often related to a wildland fire. For example, the circular pattern of an airtanker in the vicinity of a wildland fire, waiting to make a retardant drop.
label: orbit

definition: Means of establishing a flight path to a target on a fire by referring to clock directions from the aircraft's present location, with the nose of the aircraft pointing at 12:00.
label: clock method

definition: Condition or degree of being completely ready to cope with a potential fire situation.
label: readiness (fire)

definition: The aerated solution created by forcing air into, or entraining air in water containing a foam concentrate by means of suitably designed equipment or by cascading it through the air at a high velocity. Foam reduces combustion by cooling, moistening and excluding oxygen.
label: foam

definition: Time between application of an ignition source and self-sustained combustion of a fuel.
label: ignition time

definition: A search technique dividing the specific origin area into lanes that are parallel to the advancing fire progression for the purpose of a systematic examination.
label: parallel lane technique

definition: Burning by means of strip firing.
label: strip burning (firing)

definition: The foam production process of forcing air into or entraining air in foam solution, creating a mass of bubbles.
label: foam generation

definition: Setting fire inside a control line to consume fuel between the edge of the fire and the control line.
label: burn out

definition: A fire set along the inner edge of a fireline to consume the fuel in the path of a wildfire or change the direction of force of the fire's convection column.
label: backfire

definition: A map maintained on a large fire to show at given times the location of the fire, deployment of suppression forces, and progress of suppression.
label: fire progress map

definition: Sometimes referred to as "alligatoring", where combustible material appears to have a fissured or scaly appearance similar to an alligator's hide. Most commonly associated with finished lumber products, such as boards and fence posts.
label: depth of char indicators

definition: A job-related test of work capacity designed for those with moderately strenuous duties. This test consists a two-mile hike with a 25-pound pack. A time of 30 minutes, the passing score for this test, approximates an aerobic fitness score of 40.
label: field test

definition: Agency-specific accounting data.  Each agency assigns a specific accounting code to an incident.
label: accounting code

definition: Material (usually a flammable liquid) used to initiate or increase the spread of a fire.
label: accelerant

definition: Cost reports utilized for financial obligation purposes.
label: accrual reports

definition: The height above the surface of the ground to which a tree canopy is scorched.
label: crown scorch height

definition: Recommended amount of aerially applied retardant keyed to the NFDRS fuel models and/or fire behavior models. Coverage level 2 represents 2 gallons of retardant per hundred square feet. Levels range from 1 to 6 for most fuel models. A coverage level of greater than 6 is for heavy fuels. The levels can be adjusted for fire behavior.
label: coverage level

definition: The portion of a prescribed fire plan, incident action plan, or implementation plan that identifies possible but unlikely events and the contingency resources needed to mitigate those events.
label: contingency plan

definition: Tasks given to resources to perform within a given operational period, based upon tactical objectives in the incident action plan.
label: assignments

definition: An advantageous location, usually a barrier to fire spread, from which to start constructing a fireline. The anchor point is used to minimize the chance of being flanked by the fire while the line is being constructed.
label: anchor point

definition: Method of broadcast burning in which fire is ignited in the center of the area to create a strong draft; additional fires are then ignited progressively nearer the outer control lines (sometimes in one step) as indraft increases so as to draw the flames and smoke toward the center.
label: center firing

definition: An extreme rapid decomposition of a material in which the reaction is more than a sonic velocity, for example, high explosives.
label: detonation

definition: Refers to federal, state, and local cooperative fire programs.
label: co-op fire

definition: Browning of needles or leaves in the crown of a tree or shrub caused by heating to lethal temperature during a fire. Crown scorch may not be apparent for several weeks after the fire.
label: crown scorch

definition: A source category of air pollution that generally extends over a large area. Prescribed burning, field burning, home heating, and open burning are examples of area sources.
label: area source

definition: Fuels resulting from, or altered by, forestry practices such as timber harvest or thinning, as opposed to naturally created fuels.
label: activity fuels

definition: Functional unit within the Finance/Administration Section responsible for collecting all cost data, performing cost effectiveness analyses, and providing cost estimates and cost saving advice.
label: Cost Unit

definition: To consume fuel during rapid combustion.
label: burn (consumption)

definition: A component of NWCG standards. They enable consistent and uniform performance by personnel mobilized by position under NIMS-ICS principles. Position qualification requirements include training, experience, physical fitness, position currency and incident position descriptions (duties and responsibilities).
label: position qualification requirement

definition: Activities directed at reducing the incidence of human-caused wildfires, including public education, law enforcement, personal contact, and other actions taken to reduce ignitions.
label: prevention

definition: NWCG standards establish common practicesthat enable efficient and coordinated national interagency wildland fire operations. These standards maybe comprised ofrequirements,guidelines, procedures, processes, best practices, specifications, techniques, and methods. NWCG standards are interagency by design; however, the decision to adopt and utilize them is made independently by the individual member agencies and communicated through their respective directives systems.
label: NWCG standards

definition: A general alert from an NWCG committee to the wildland fire community regarding the release of subject-specific information such as technical information, equipment updates, accident reports, etc. Depending on the origin and/or the subject content, a green hash-marked bordered stationary may be associated with this type of alert.
label: bulletin
related term: Safety Alert, Safety Advisory, Safety Warning, Safety Bulletin

definition: A method used to distribute various types of general or time-sensitive information from an NWCG committee to the wildland fire community. Information may include bulletins, advisories, or safety warnings, each with an associated color hash-marked bordered stationary.
label: Alert System
related term: Safety Alert, Safety Advisory, Safety Warning, Safety Bulletin

definition: A safety alert addressing wildland fire safety information that isn't related to imminent or potential threats of injury.
label: Safety Advisory
related term: Safety Alert, bulletin, Safety Warning, Alert System

definition: A safety alert addressing wildland fire safety hazards that pose an imminent threat, or have potential to pose a threat, to life or property.
label: Safety Warning
related term: Safety Alert, Safety Advisory, bulletin, Safety Bulletin, Alert System

definition: A special fire weather forecast for a specific fire prepared by a meteorologist on site at or near the fire area.
label: mobile weather unit forecast (fire)

definition: A special weather forecast for a specific incident prepared by a meteorologist on site at or near the incident area.
label: mobile weather unit forecast (incident)

definition: A warm, dry and strong general wind that flows down into the valleys when stable, high pressure air is forced across and then down the lee slopes of a mountain range. The descending air is warmed and dried due to adiabatic compression producing critical fire weather conditions. Locally called by various names such as Santa Ana winds, Devil winds, North winds, Mono winds, etc.
label: Foehn wind
alternative label: Devil winds, Santa Ana winds, Mono winds, North winds

definition: According to the American Meteorological Society, the process of transport of an atmospheric property solely by the mass motion of the atmosphere; also the rate of change of the value of the advected property at a given point.
label: advection

definition: A name given to an ordinary thermometer used to determine the temperature of the air (to distinguish it from the wet bulb).
label: dry bulb

definition: Period(s) of the year during which wildland fires are likely to occur, spread, and affect resources values sufficient to warrant organized fire management activities.
label: fire season (likelihood)

definition: The front that is formed when and where a cold front overtakes a warm front or a stationary front.
label: occluded front or occlusion

definition: A forecast for a period extending from about two days to five days or a week in advance; there are no absolute limits to the period embraced by this definition.
label: medium-range forecast

definition: Plot of the actual dry-bulb temperature against height above the earth's surface, most commonly determined by a RAWINSONDE observation.
label: vertical temperature profile

definition: The reduction in forest floor thickness due to consumption by fire.
label: Depth of Burn

definition: A divergent wind field. Storms moving into a split field tend to lose strength. Winds are generally light in such a flow field.
label: split flow

definition: Target area for airtankers, helitankers, cargo dropping.
label: Drop Zone

definition: A wildfire response strategy of restricting a wildfire to a defined area, primarily using natural barriers that are expected to restrict the spread of the wildfire under the prevailing and forecasted weather conditions.
label: confine
definition extension: Some response action may be required to augment or connect natural barriers (e.g. line construction, burn-out, bucket drops, etc.).

definition: The status of a wildfire suppression action signifying that a control line has been completed around the fire, and any associated spot fires, which can reasonably be expected to stop the fire's spread.
label: containment (wildfire)

definition: The orderly collection, analysis, and interpretation of environmental data to evaluate management's progress toward meeting objectives, and to identify changes in natural systems. Monitoring is also conducted on wildland fires to observe fire effects, fire behavior, or both. For example, the work done by Fire Effects Monitor (FEMO) or Field Observer (FOBS) positions.
label: monitoring

definition: All the work to extinguish or limit wildland fire spread.
label: suppression
related term: point/zone protection, suppress a fire, confine

definition: An airborne irritating, noxious, or toxic smoke, vapor, or any combination of these produced by a volatile substance or a chemical reaction.
label: fume

definition: The generic name for a high-strength, flame-resistant, synthetic fabric used in the shirts and jeans of firefighters. Nomex  , a brand name for aramid fabric, is the term commonly used by firefighters.
label: Aramid
editorial note: JK-checked.  Nomex ® needs to be added as a related term.

definition: Any fire in which the predominant fuel is grass or grasslike.
label: grass fire

definition: Flashlight, ordinarily worn by firefighter on the front of the helmet.
label: headlamp

definition: Location at which primary command functions are executed. The ICP may be collocated with the incident base or other incident facilities.
label: Incident Command Post

definition: A wildland fuel that is suspended off the ground in such a way that fire may burn both over and under it.
label: suspended fuel
definition extension: Heated air and fire moving under the suspended fuel wraps around the backside due to wind vortex flame wrap creating a fire pattern indicator the opposite of a typical protection fire pattern indicator.

definition: A fire edge that crosses a control line or natural barrier intended to confine the fire.
label: slopover

definition: A ground service vehicle capable of supplying fuel and support equipment to helicopters.
label: helicopter tender

definition: A pre-determined complement of tools, equipment and/or supplies stored in a designated location, available for incident use.
label: cache

definition: Load of hose specially arranged on top of a standard hose load to permit dropping the working line at the fire.
label: skid hose load

definition: The product of the available heat of combustion per unit of ground and the rate of spread of the fire, interpreted as the heat released per unit of time for each unit length of fire edge. The primary unit is Btu per second per foot (Btu/sec/ft) of fire front.
label: fireline intensity (heat release)

definition: A nozzle is designed to provide either a solid stream or a fixed spray pattern suitable for applying water, wet water or foam solution.
label: combination nozzle

definition: Efforts undertaken within three years of a wildland fire to repair or improve fire damaged lands unlikely to recover to a management approved conditions or to repair or replace minor facilities damaged by fire.
label: rehabilitation

definition: The post-fire activities prescribed and implemented to rehabilitate and restore fire damaged lands.
label: burned area rehabilitation

definition: Any substance that can cause or contribute to the production of cancer.
label: carcinogen

definition: Elapsed time from receipt of notification by the personnel charged with initiating suppression action to the departure of the first attack unit.
label: getaway time

definition: A collapsible backpack portable sprayer made of neoprene or high-strength nylon fabric fitted with a pump.
label: bladder bag

definition: A portable sprayer with hand-pump, fed from a liquid filled container fitted with straps, used mainly in fire and pest control.
label: backpack pump

definition: The command staff consists of the information officer, safety officer and liaison officer. They report directly to the incident commander and may have an assistant or assistants, as needed.
label: command staff

definition: A particularly active part of a fire.
label: hotspot

definition: Total time a fuel can burn and continue to feed energy to the base of a forward-traveling convection column.
label: critical burnout time

definition: Any incident which requires the response of a fire protection organization's attack units and/or support units.
label: emergency

definition: Private sector personnel, vendor or business contracted to provide goods and services to a government agency.
label: contractor

definition: To travel over a given route to prevent, detect, and suppress fires. Includes interaction with the public for wildland fire prevention and educational purposes.
label: patrol (prevention)

definition: Portion of human-caused fires that have occurred on a protection unit chargeable to a specific risk source; calculated for each day of the week for each risk source.
label: risk source ratio

definition: Retardant drop made from one compartment at a time from an airtanker with a multi-compartment tank.
label: split drop

definition: Acceptance of information as true without proof or demonstration.
label: assumption

definition: In hazard reduction, burning narrow strips of fuel and leaving the rest of the area untreated by fire.
label: strip burning (hazard reduction)

definition: Prominent ridgeline separating river or creek drainages. Usually has numerous smaller ridges (spur) extending outward from both sides.
label: main ridge

definition: A control strategy used in managing smoke from prescribed fires in which smoke concentration is reduced by diluting it through a greater volume of air, either by scheduling during good dispersion conditions or burning at a slower rate.
label: dilution
editorial note: JK-checked.  Related term "display class" is not shown in NWCG.

definition: A reference to a working fire.
label: burn (fire)
editorial note: JK-checked.  NWCG also shows RMC which is not shown below.

definition: A boundary designated by governmental agencies (wildland fire protection agencies), that may coincide with a geographic area boundary or may be a subdivision of a geographic area within which they work together coordinating, for the effective, mobilization and demobilization of emergency management resources within their area. Listings of geographic coordinating areas and geographic coordination centers can be found in the National Interagency Mobilization Guide, Chapter 20, Section 21.1.
label: geographic coordinating area
related term: Geographic Area Coordination Center, geographic area

definition: A boundary designated by governmental agencies (wildland fire protection agencies) within which they work together for the interagency, intergovernmental planning, coordination, and operations leadership for the effective utilization of emergency management resources within their area. There are ten geographic areas. A listing of the areas can be found in the National Interagency Mobilization Guide, Chapter 70 along with listings of the Geographic Coordinating Areas and Geographic Area Coordination Centers.
label: geographic area
related term: Geographic Area Coordination Center, geographic coordinating area

definition: The physical location of an interagency, regional operation center for the effective coordination, mobilization and demobilization of emergency management resources. A coordination center serves federal, state and local wildland fire agencies through logistical coordination of resources throughout the geographic area, and with other geographic areas, as well. Listings of geographic coordination centers and their respective geographic coordinating areas can be found within the National Interagency Mobilization Guide.
label: Geographic Area Coordination Center

definition: Weight of a truck empty (without payload and driver) but ready to drive, including a full fuel tank, cooling system, crankcase, tools, spare wheel, and all other equipment specified as standard.
label: curb weight

definition: The process in which teams of professional and peer counselors provide emotional and psychological support to incident personnel who are or have been involved in a critical (highly stressful) incident.
label: Critical Incident Stress Debriefing

definition: The taking or keeping of a person in custody by legal authority, especially in response to a criminal charge.
label: arrest

definition: Include property, structures, physical improvements, natural and cultural resources, community infrastructure, and economic, environmental, and social values.
label: values to be protected

definition: The natural resources of an area, such as timber, grass, watershed values, recreation values, and wildlife habitat.
label: resources (natural)

definition: An incident, natural or human-caused, that requires an organized response by a public, private, and/or governmental entity to protect life, public health and safety, values to be protected, and to minimize any disruption of governmental, social, and economic services. One or more kinds of incident (fire, flood, mass casualty, search, rescue, evacuation, etc.) may occur simultaneously as part of an all hazard incident response.
label: all hazard incident

definition: An occurrence either human-caused or natural phenomenon, that requires action or support by emergency service personnel to prevent or minimize loss of life or damage to property and/or natural resources.
label: incident

definition: Removing branches from a felled or standing tree, or from brush.
label: limbing

definition: Fire which has exceeded or is expected to exceed initial attack capabilities or prescription.
label: escaped fire

definition: The elements of a community or natural area considered valuable by an individual or community that could be negatively impacted by a wildfire or wildfire operations. These values can vary by community and can include diverse characteristics such as homes, specific structures, water supply, power grids, natural and cultural resources, community infrastructure, and other economic, environmental, and social values.
label: values at risk

definition: Device that connects the ends of adjacent hoses or other components of hose.
label: coupling

definition: A device for connecting hoses of the same size with non-matching hose threads, or connecting a threaded coupling to a quick-connect coupling.
label: adapter

definition: A board or committee selected to review results of fire suppression action on a given unit or the specific action taken on a given fire. The board reviews the results in order to identify reasons for both good and poor action and to recommend or prescribe ways and means of doing an effective and efficient job. Reviews the results of a safety/accident investigation.
label: board of review

definition: The process and procedures used by all organizations, federal, state and local, for activating, assembling, and transporting all resources that have been requested to respond to or support an incident.
label: mobilization

definition: Military Operations Area found on aeronautical charts.
label: Military Operations Area
editorial note: gb - seems like an incomplete definition. This is what is on wikipedia and is a better definition in my opinion: an airspace established outside Class A airspace to separate or segregate certain nonhazardous military activities from IFR Traffic and to identify for VFR traffic where these activities are conducted

definition: Activities in advance of fire occurrence to ensure effective suppression action. Includes planning the organization, recruiting and training, procuring equipment and supplies, maintaining fire equipment and fire control improvements, and negotiating cooperative and/or mutual aid agreements.
label: presuppression

definition: Dead fuels consisting of roundwood in the size range of 1 to 3 inches (2.5 to 7.6 cm) in diameter and very roughly the layer of litter extending from approximately three-fourths of an inch (1.9 cm) to 4 inches (10 cm) below the surface.
label: one-hundred hour timelag fuels

definition: The moisture content of the 100-hour timelag fuels.
label: One-hundred Hour Timelag Fuel Moisture
related term: one-thousand hour timelag fuels, one-hundred hour timelag fuels

definition: Dead fuels consisting of roundwood 3-8 inches in diameter and the layer of the forest floor more than about 4 inches below the surface.
label: one-thousand hour timelag fuels
related term: One-thousand Hour Timelag Fuel Moisture, One-hour Timelag Fuel Moisture, One-hundred Hour Timelag Fuel Moisture

definition: Wildland fire-related mishap that results in serious or non-serious injuries involving multiple personnel, near accident (which would have resulted in a serious injury or fatality), or substantial loss of property (less than $250,000). The mishap may be so complex and fraught with operational discrepancies that it has the potential to produce an accident, serious injury, or fatality given a similar environment or set of circumstances that existed at the time of the incident.
label: incident with potential

definition: Any potential accident which, through prevention, education, hazard reduction, or luck, did not occur.
label: near miss

definition: Map showing the different classes of visible area covered by a lookout point or points; may differentiate between seen areas, indirectly visible areas, and blind areas, or only between seen areas and blind areas. Also known as seen area map.
label: visible area map
editorial note:
SMS
this term not found in NWCG Glossary

definition: An off-incident location at which emergency service personnel and equipment are temporarily located pending assignment, release, or reassignment.
label: mobilization center

definition: Determination of position by one or more radio navigational aids.
label: radio fix

definition: The relative change of some measurable quantity with change of temperature, like burning time per unit length, mostly expressed as mean change per degree in percentage of mean temperature within a certain range.
label: temperature coefficient

definition: Individuals within ICS organizational units that are assigned specific managerial responsibilities, e.g., staging area manager or camp manager.
label: managers

definition: Functional unit within the Logistics Section responsible for providing meals for incident personnel.
label: Food Unit

definition: The ICS section responsible for providing facilities, services, and supplies in support of an incident.
label: Logistics Section
narrower term: Facilities Unit, Medical Unit, Food Unit, Support Branch, Ground Support Unit

definition: The satellite used for data relay from NFDRS weather stations to ASCADS.
label: Geostationary Operational Environmental Satellite

definition: A uniform fire danger rating system that focuses on the environmental factors that control the moisture content of fuels.
label: National Fire Danger Rating System
related term: Fire Danger Rating System, Geostationary Operational Environmental Satellite, staffing index

definition: A NFDRS component, index or related indicator (ignition component, spread component, energy release component, burning index, Keetch-Byram drought index) whose outputs are correlated to the local fire problem, used to determine staffing levels.
label: staffing index
related term: spread component, Keetch-Byram Drought Index, National Fire Danger Rating System, burning index (fire behavior), Energy Release Component, ignition component

definition: The complete program necessary to produce and apply fire danger ratings, including data collection, data processing, fire danger modeling, communications, and data storage.
label: Fire Danger Rating System

definition: Contrivance designed and used to start a fire.
label: incendiary device

definition: A specially prepared stick or set of sticks of known dry weight continuously exposed to the weather and periodically weighed to determine changes in moisture content as an indication of moisture changes in wildland fuels.
label: fuel moisture indicator stick

definition: Small capacity spray jet produced at very high pressures (greater than 250 psi, the normal maximum pressure for standard ground tankers) and discharged through a small hose with a gun-type nozzle.
label: high pressure fog

definition: Rapid oxidation, usually with the evolution of heat and light; heat fuel, oxygen and interaction of the three.
label: fire

definition: Removal or killing of unwanted vegetation, residue, etc. by use of fire, herbicides, or mechanical treatment in preparation for reforestation and future management.
label: site preparation

definition: An estimate of the potential difficulty of fire containment as it relates to the flame length at the head of the fire.
label: burning index (flame length)

definition: A system for, or the act of discovering, locating, and reporting fires from aircraft.
label: aerial detection

definition: System for airplane landing in which the pilot is guided by radio beams.
label: Instrument Landing System

definition: The parts of a fire’s perimeter that are roughly parallel to the main direction of fire spread.
label: flanks of a fire (fire spread)

definition: Specially designed bucket carried by a helicopter like a sling load and used for aerial delivery of water or fire retardants.
label: helibucket

definition: A person working within an agency organization who processes resources to and from incidents.
label: agency dispatcher
editorial note: JK-checked.  Missing related term "dispatcher" - wasn't sure which list it needed to be in to add for linking.

definition: A declared ban on open air burning within a specified area, usually due to sustained high fire danger.
label: burning ban

definition: Functional unit within the support branch of the logistics section responsible for ordering equipment and supplies required for incident operations.
label: Supply Unit

definition: A branch within the logistics section responsible for providing personnel, equipment and supplies to support incident operations. Includes the supply, facilities and ground support units.
label: Support Branch
narrower term: Facilities Unit, Supply Unit, Ground Support Unit

definition: Direct attack with multiple anchor points, that allows for multiple points of attack. Generally used as an engine tactic in the wildland urban interface.
label: envelopment

definition: That portion of a fire edge opposite the head.
label: rear (of a fire) (opposite the head)

definition: That portion of a fire backing directly away from and in relatively close proximity to the ignition area. The slowest spreading portion of a fire edge and generally opposite the head.
label: heel of the fire
related term: rear (of a fire) (opposite the head), parts of a fire, head of the fire

definition: The most rapidly spreading portions of a fires perimeter, usually progressing with the wind, up slope, or a combination of the two.
label: head of the fire
related term: parts of a fire, heel of the fire

definition: Different areas of the fire usually determined by the predominant direction of fire spread and delineated from the fastest moving area (head) to the slowest moving area (base or tail). The most rapidly moving portion is designated the head of the fire, the adjoining portions of the perimeter at right angles to the head are known as the flanks, and the slowest moving portion is known as the rear or the base of the fire.
label: parts of a fire
related term: heel of the fire, head of the fire

definition: A near scale depiction of the scene based on measurements and data.
label: fire diagram

definition: Smoke which becomes visible only at intervals.
label: intermittent smoke

definition: Fingers or islands of less intensely burned areas or areas where the fire has self extinguished.
label: die-out pattern indicators

definition: Positive displacement pump which uses closely meshed gears to propel water when high pressures and low volumes are desired; can be used safely only with clear water-- suspended particles of soil or rocks can quickly wear the gears and reduce pressure and volume of water.
label: gear pump

definition: In general, an actionable fire, on which any fire agency reports and maintains specified information (e.g., cause, date and point of origin, size, fire damage).
label: statistical fire

definition: Activities that lead to a safe, efficient, and cost-effective fire management program in support of land and resource management objectives through appropriate planning and coordination.
label: preparedness (activity)

definition: The address where the unit must be physically located, and dispatched from, during the mandatory availability period.
label: Designated Dispatch Point

Glossary Term: Lookout(s), Communication(s), Escape Route(s), and Safety Zone(s)
definition: Elements of a safety system used by fire fighters to routinely assess their current situation with respect to wildland firefighting hazards.
label: Lookout(s), Communication(s), Escape Route(s), and Safety Zone(s)

definition: A fire-trenching or digging tool having a sharp, tempered blade, which is useful for heavy grubbing, trenching, and light cutting.
label: Adze Hoe

definition: An individual who has met all required training and position experience for a specified position and is approved by their home unit's certifying official, to initiate a performance based training assignment in order to become qualified in the position.
label: trainee

definition: A document listing the performance requirements (competencies and behaviors) for a position in a format that allows for the evaluation of individual (trainee) performance to determine if an individual is qualified in the position. Successful performance of PTB tasks, as observed and recorded by a qualified evaluator, will result in a recommendation to the trainee's home unit that the individual be certified in the position.
label: Position Task Book
related term: certifying official, competency, behavior, position performance assignment, agency certification, final evaluator, trainee, home unit (designated), evaluator

definition: The process whereby the employing agency or contractor documents that the individual is fully qualified to perform duties and responsibilities for a specified position.
label: agency certification
editorial note: JK-checked.  Related terms listed in EDG not listed in NWCG.
related term: certifying official, Position Task Book, evaluator

definition: The individual who is qualified in the position being evaluated, or supervises the position being evaluated, having responsibility for observing task(s) being performed and documenting successful performance for agency certification or re-certification. Evaluator responsibilities must remain separate from the individual assigned as Trainer/Coach.
label: evaluator
related term: agency certification, re-certification, Position Task Book, trainer/coach

definition: The agency official at the home unit who is responsible for authorizing and granting position certification per agency policy. The agency official is responsible for completing the agency certification block located on the inside front cover of a Position Task Book.
label: certifying official
related term: agency certification, Position Task Book, home unit (designated)

definition: A broad description that groups core behaviors necessary to perform a specific function.
label: competency
editorial note: JK-checked.  Related term "Position Task Book" not listed in NWCG.

definition: An observable activity or action demonstrated by an individual in a particular context.
label: behavior
editorial note: JK-checked.  "Position Task Book", and "task" both listed as related terms, but not shown in NWCG.

definition: The designated agency or entity providing contracted resources that employs the individual who is actively pursuing a position performance assignment (completion of a position task book).
label: home unit (designated)
related term: certifying official, position performance assignment, Position Task Book

definition: The individual responsible for completing the position task book's verification statement once all tasks in the position task book have been completed and signed off. Only the evaluator on the final position performance assignment (the assignment in which all remaining tasks have been evaluated and signed off) will complete the verification statement recommending certification.
label: final evaluator
related term: position performance assignment, Position Task Book

definition: An assignment in which an individual is being evaluated for tasks found in the position task book.
label: position performance assignment
related term: final evaluator, Position Task Book, home unit (designated)

definition: Specified information relating to the intended flight of an aircraft that is filed orally or in writing with an air traffic control facility.
label: flight path (intended)

definition: In FireFamily Plus, a day with both a weather observation and at least one large (as defined by the user) fire.
label: large fire-day

definition: Standard 24-hour period beginning at 1000 hours, during which most wildfires undergo a predictable speeding up and slowing down of intensity, depending primarily on the influence of weather and fuel factors.
label: fire-day, fire day

definition: In FireFamily Plus, a day with both a weather observation and a number of fires equal to or greater than that determined by the user to be a significant workload.
label: multiple fire-day

definition: Miniature whirlwinds trailing from the wingtips of any aircraft in flight. Vortex will be in the form of a horizontal whirlwind with velocities up to 25 mph (40 km) per hour or more. Also created by action of rotor blades on helicopters; these whirlwinds tend to move downward toward the ground. If an aircraft flies low over a fire, vortices may reach the ground and suddenly cause violent and erratic fire behavior.
label: vortex turbulence

definition: Common type of fire hose nozzle permitting stream flow to be controlled by the firefighter at the nozzle rather than only at the source of supply.
label: shutoff nozzle

definition: Term used in calculating from performance charts the permissible helicopter payload at which a helicopter is capable of hovering in ground effect or hovering out of ground effect, based on pressure altitude and air temperature.
label: computed gross weight

definition: The time from the moment the aircraft first moves under its own power for the purpose of flight until the moment it comes to rest at the next point of landing.
label: flight time

definition: Wheels powered by all of the vehicle's drive axles. Dual tires are considered as single wheels. The number of wheels is commonly referenced by the terms "4x2", "4x4", etc. where the first figure indicates the total number of wheels on the ground and the second figure, the number of drive wheels.
label: drive wheels

definition: A two way radio unit on mobile apparatus (instead of base stations), usually semi-permanently attached to the apparatus.

definition: A person who fells trees.

definition: Those areas identified as principal population centers or other areas requiring protection under state or federal air quality laws or regulations.

definition: Confirmation through the re-issuance of an incident qualification card that an individual has regained qualifications for a specified position that was lost through a lack of current experience. definition: A shallow channel or raised barrier, e.g., a ridge of packed earth or a thin pole laid diagonally across the surface of a road or trail so as to lead off water, particularly storm water. (Frequently installed in firelines on steep slopes to prevent erosion.)

definition: Number relating human-caused fire incidence to the ignition component in a fire danger rating area. It is based on three to five years of fire occurrence and fire weather data that adjusts the prediction of the basic human-caused fire occurrence model to fit local experience.

definition: Ignition and subsequent envelopment in flames, usually from bottom to top, of a tree or small group of trees.

definition: That part of the fire on which work is started when suppression crews arrive.

definition: Starting a fire, usually deliberately and maliciously.
label: firesetting

definition: Person who starts a fire, usually deliberately and maliciously.

definition: In fire danger rating, a subjective estimate of the degree of activity of a potential human-caused fire source relative to that which is normally experienced. Five activity levels are defined: none, low, normal, high, and extreme.

definition extension: Part of the National Fire Danger Rating System (NFDRS).

definition: Any item which can produce sufficient heat over a sufficient duration of time capable of bringing forest fuels to their ignition temperature and sustain open flame combustion.

definition: Smoke from prescribed fire entering a designated area at unacceptable levels.

definition: The basis for decision support for daily staffing of initial attack resources and other activities. A level of readiness and an indicator or daily preparedness.

definition: A course or courses that must be completed prior to initiating a position task book. definition: see: Suppression

definition: The set of responsibilities and ethical considerations that define the extent or limits of the care provider within the current standards of practice.

definition: The process by which a helicopter fills a helibucket while hovering above the water source.

definition: Immediate area where a fire shelter has been deployed.

definition: Removing a fire shelter from its case and unfolding it to use as protection against heat, smoke, and burning embers.
