definition: A supply of fire tools and equipment assembled in planned quantities or standard units at a strategic point for exclusive use in fire suppression.
label: fire cache

definition: A calculated reduction in actual payload to provide a margin of safety.
label: downloading

definition: A search technique dividing the specific origin area into lanes that are perpendicular to the advancing fire progression for the purpose of a systematic examination.
label: perpendicular lane technique

definition: Direction given by the operations section chief which includes the tactics appropriate for the selected strategy, the selection and assignment of resources, tactics implementation, and performance monitoring for each operational period.
label: tactical direction

definition: Any aircraft equipped to pick up water while moving on or over water.
label: skimmer

definition: Use of two or more fire pumps to move water a distance which would require excessive pressures in order to overcome friction loss if only one pump were employed at the source.
label: relay

definition: All combustible materials below the surface litter, including duff, tree or shrub roots, punky wood, peat, and sawdust, that normally support a glowing combustion without flame.
label: ground fuel

definition: The distribution of an aerially delivered retardant drop on the target area in terms of its length, width, and momentum (velocity x mass) as it approaches the ground. The latter determines the relative coverage level of the fire retardant on fuels within the pattern.
label: drop pattern

definition: The distribution of an aerially delivered retardant drop on the target area in terms of its length, width, and momentum (velocity x mass) as it approaches the ground. The latter determines the relative coverage level of the fire retardant on fuel within the pattern.
label: pattern

definition: A fixed tank attached to the belly of the helicopter that has a pump-driven snorkel attached. The helicopter hovers over the water source with the end of the snorkel immersed, the pump then fills the tank.
label: snorkel tank

definition: Maximum water flow rate a fire pump will attain when there are no restrictions at the pump outlet or losses due to friction or head.
label: free flow (hydraulics)

definition: An area that has reburned.
label: reburn (historical)

definition: Qualitative risk assessment is the application of judgment based in knowledge and experience when assessing wildfire risk, the potential for ignitions and recommendations regarding possible ways to mitigate the risk.
label: qualitative risk assessment
risk assessment
related term: qualitative risk assessment, quantitative risk assessment

definition: Quantitative risk assessments provide a method by which we can calculate risk based on measurements or estimates of various risk components such as likelihood of fire occurrence, intensity of fire should it occur, and susceptibility to fire of the various values being evaluated.
label: quantitative risk assessment

definition: Recording instrument combining, on one paper record, the variation of dry-bulb temperature and relative humidity as a function of time.
label: hygrothermograph

definition: Contains objectives reflecting the overall incident strategy and specific tactical actions and supporting information for the next operational period. The plan may be oral or written. When written, the plan may have a number of attachments, including: incident objectives, organization assignment list, division assignment, incident radio communication plan, medical plan, traffic plan, safety plan, and incident map. Formerly called shift plan.
label: Incident Action Plan

definition: Any tactical plan developed by any element of ICS in support of the incident action plan.
label: action plan

definition: An externally threaded hose nipple which fits in the thread of a female (internally threaded) swivel coupling of the same pitch and diameter. Nozzles attach to this type of coupling.
label: male coupling

definition: Any agent which retards a chemical reaction.
label: inhibitor

definition: Sudden increase in wind speed to at least 17 mph (15 knots) that is sustained for at least 1 minute but not more than 5 minutes.
label: squall

definition: A formal working agreement among agencies to obtain mutual aid.
label: compact

definition: A fireline trench on the downhill side of fire burning on steep slopes that is supposed to be built deep enough to catch rolling firebrands that could otherwise start fire below the fireline. A high berm on the outermost downhill side of the trench helps the cup trench catch material.
label: cup trench
editorial note: JK-checked.  Related term "undercut line" not listed in NWCG, but shown in EDG.

definition: A fireline below a fire on a slope. Should be trenched to catch rolling material.
label: undercut line

definition: Condition in which obscuring phenomenon restricts horizontal visibility to six statute miles (10 km.) or less.
label: obstruction to vision

definition: The act of determining that a fire exists; does not include determining its location.
label: fire discovery

definition: The point or points of origin of an incendiary fire.
label: set (point of origin)

definition: A low expansion foam type with no expansion, therefore lacking bubble structure, which is used for mopup and flame knock down.
label: foam solution

definition: An unplanned event that does substantial damage or causes serious injuries when associated with the operation of applicable aircraft. Event occurs between the time engine(s) is (are) started or rotors turning for the purpose of commencing flight, until the aircraft comes to rest with engines and propellers or rotors stopped, the brakes set or wheel chocks in place, and all persons have disembarked.
label: aircraft accident

definition: The policies and practices implemented by air and natural resource managers directed at minimizing the amount of smoke entering populated areas or impacting sensitive sites, avoiding significant deterioration of air quality and violations of National Ambient Air Quality Standards, and mitigating human-caused visibility impacts in Class I areas.
label: smoke management

definition: Burning material at the points deliberately ignited for backfiring, slash burning, prescribed burning, and other purposes.
label: set (planned)

definition: Extensive, thick blanket of smoke spreading more or less horizontally from a fire.
label: smoke pall

definition: Ratio of the amount of water to the amount of dry plant material in living plants.
label: live fuel moisture content

definition: The ground area covered by the crown of a tree as delimited by the vertical projection of its outermost perimeter.
label: crown cover

definition: Water with added chemicals, called wetting agents, that increase water's spreading and penetrating properties due to a reduction in surface tension.
label: wet water

definition: A layer of foam which forms an insulating and reflective barrier to heat and is used for fuel protection, suppression, and mopup.
label: foam blanket

definition: The distance from the centerline of the front axle to the centerline of the rear axle. For a tandem rear axle vehicle the center line is midpoint between the centers of the two rear axles.
label: wheelbase

definition: A small rotor, mounted on the tail of a conventional helicopter, which counteracts torque of the main rotor and provides a measure of directional control.
label: tail rotor

definition: A daily safety briefing for wildland fire that focuses on high risk events found within a firefighter's scope of work that are performed on an infrequent basis.
label: Six Minutes for Safety
definition extension: View the Six Minutes for Safety website: NWCG Executive Board site at https://www.nwcg.gov/committee/6mfs

definition: Setting fire inside a control line to consume fuel located between the edge of the fire and the control line.
label: burning out

definition: The relative difficulty of constructing control line as determined by the fuel, topography, and soil.
label: resistance to line construction

definition: The range of options available for response to a wildfire.
label: wildfire response strategies

definition: Rapid fluctuations in wind speed with a variation of 10 knots (11.5 mph) or more between peaks and lulls.
label: gust

definition: Daily, especially pertaining to cyclic actions which are completed within 24 hours, and which recur every 24 hours, such as temperature, relative humidity and wind.
label: diurnal

definition: An instrument that provides an approximate measure of evapotranspiration by measuring the water loss from an artificial evaporating surface.
label: atmometer

definition: Chipping or pitting of concrete, masonry, or stone surfaces.
label: spalling

definition: Abbreviated (NH) for national hose. Specifically defined screw thread used on fire hose couplings.
label: National Standard Thread

definition: Any obstruction to the spread of fire. Typically an area or strip devoid of combustible fuel.
label: barrier

definition: The quantity of moisture in fuel expressed as a percentage of the weight when thoroughly dried at 212 degrees F.
label: fuel moisture content

definition: In NFDRS, a calculated value representing the approximate moisture content of the live woody vegetation in the rating area expressed as a percentage of the oven dry weight of the sample.
label: woody fuel moisture
definition extension: Part of the National Fire Danger Rating System (NFDRS).
related term: herbaceous fuel moisture, measured woody fuel moisture

definition: In NFDRS, a calculated value representing the approximate moisture content of the live herbaceous vegetation in the rating area expressed as a percentage of the oven dry weight of the sample.
label: herbaceous fuel moisture
definition extension: Part of the National Fire Danger Rating System (NFDRS).

definition: Moisture content of the small branch wood and foliage of live woody plants, expressed as a percentage of the oven dry weight of the sample, collected monthly and used to supplement NFDRS modeled outputs.
label: measured woody fuel moisture

definition: Delineated area surrounding a base which can be reached first by the ground or air attack units assigned to the base.
label: area of influence

definition: An area that, in relation to wildland/urban fire, has a set of conditions that provides the opportunity for fire to burn from wildland vegetation to the home/structure ignition zone.
label: I-Zone

definition: Evaluation of a dwelling and its immediate surrounding to determine its potential to escape damage by an approaching wildland fire. Includes the fuels and vegetation in the yard and adjacent to the structure, roof environment, decking and siding materials, prevailing winds, topography, fire history, etc., with the intent of mitigating fire hazards and risks.
label: home assessment

definition: A crew of firefighters specially trained and certified in the tactical and logistical use of helicopters for fire suppression.
label: helitack crew

definition: The utilization of helicopters to transport crews, equipment, and fire retardants or suppressants to the fireline during the initial stages of a fire. The term also refers to the crew that performs helicopter management and attack activities.
label: helitack
editorial note: gb - should we break this into two terms?

definition: International distress signal/call. When repeated three times it indicates imminent and grave danger and that immediate assistance is required.
label: may day

definition: To jettison a load of water or retardant from an aircraft, or terminate a preplanned aircraft maneuver.
label: abort

definition: Annual review by an employing agency of an individual's position qualifications and documentation certifying that the individual is fully qualified to perform duties and responsibilities for a specified position. Annual certification is based on established performance standards and agency specific requirements.
label: annual certification

definition: The place where plant communities meet or where successional stages or vegetative conditions within plant communities come together.
label: edge (plant community)

definition: The amount of combustion products found in a specified volume of air, commonly expressed as micrograms of emission per cubic meter of air.
label: smoke concentration

definition: Material left to ignite an incendiary fire at a later time.
label: set (material)

definition: Two attached straight stream nozzle tips of different orifice size used to increase or restrict water flow.
label: combination nozzle tip

definition: Analysis of one or more fire scars to determine individual tree fire frequency or mean fire intervals for specified areas.
label: fire scar analysis

definition: The characteristic configuration of char left by a fire. In wildland fires burn patterns are influenced by topography, wind direction, length of exposure, and type of fuel. Definitions are scale-dependent: (1) They can be used to trace a fire's origin; (2) They are influenced by severity and intensity within a stand; (3) They describe the landscape mosaic.
label: burn patterns (configuration)
editorial note: JK-checked.  WFISC also used by NWCG but not shown.

definition: Regular federal government employee who is compensated under the Federal Wage System and referred to as Wage Grade (WG), Wage Leader (WL), or Wage Supervisor (WS) employee.
label: Federal Wage System Employee
alternative label: Wage Grade (WG), Wage Leader (WL), Wage Supervisor (WS)

definition: The comparative differences of damage to objects resulting from the fires passage.
label: damage differential
definition extension: One of the underlying principles that govern the interpretation of most fire pattern indicators. This principle may be observed on various surfaces of individual objects or by comparing the damage within adjoining areas of the fire.

definition: A tank, usually collapsible, used as a reservoir in the relay of water from one fire pump to another.
label: relay tank

definition: Fire retardant that inhibits combustion primarily by the cooling and smothering action of water. Chemicals may be added to the water to alter its viscosity or retard its evaporation, thereby increasing its effectiveness.
label: short-term fire retardant

definition: A relative number indicating the severity of wildland fire danger as determined from burning conditions and other variable factors of fire danger.
label: fire danger index

definition: Fire weather forecast for a period greater than five days in advance.
label: long-range forecast

definition: Precipitation composed exclusively of water drops smaller than 0.02 inches (0.5 mm) in diameter.
label: drizzle

definition: Instrument for measuring the dependable range of distance at which a standard smoke column can be detected by the unaided eye under existing haze conditions.
label: haze meter

definition: A colorless, odorless, poisonous gas produced by incomplete fuel combustion.
label: Carbon Monoxide

definition: Instantaneous explosion or rapid burning of superheated gases that occurs when oxygen is introduced into an oxygen-depleted confined space. It may occur because of inadequate or improper ventilation procedures.
label: backdraft

definition: Refers to the joint consideration of both the life and physical well-being of individuals.
label: life-safety

definition: A branch within the logistics section responsible for service activities at the incident. Includes the communications, medical and food units.
label: service branch

definition: Liquid phosphate fertilizers used as fire retardants, usually diluted three to five times prior to application.
label: Liquid Concentrate

definition: Burning slash that has been piled into long continuous rows. Also includes wildfire in vegetation planted to protect improvements or agriculture.
label: windrow burning

definition: A raging, destructive fire. Often used to connote such a fire with a moving front as distinguished from a fire storm.
label: conflagration

definition: Re-ignition due to latent heat, sparks, or embers or due to presence of smoke or steam.
label: rekindle

definition: Controls the pitch angle of the main (helicopter) rotor blades. Used as primary altitude control.
label: collective control

definition: Level, in the vicinity of the fire, at which the smoke ceases to rise and moves horizontally with the wind at that level.
label: smoke vent height

definition: The act of throwing mineral soil about the base of an unlighted snag to prevent its being ignited by a surface fire.
label: banking snags

definition: Weather conditions which influence fire ignition, behavior, and suppression.
label: fire weather

definition: Testimony or information not based on actual personal knowledge or observation, but dependent on inference of other facts or experience. For example, testimony that defendant's cigarette lighter was found in ashes of a fire.
label: circumstantial evidence

definition: The burning of understory prior to the sale of forest products to improve the efficiency of timber marking and harvesting.
label: accessibility burn

definition: A thermal trauma that maybe a superficial, partial thickness or full thickness burn.
label: radiant burn

definition: Metal wrench used to tighten and free hose connections.
label: spanner

definition: Area of fuel covered and degree of coverage on the fuel by a fire retardant, usually expressed in terms of gallons per hundred square feet (liters per square meter).
label: retardant coverage

definition: North, south, east, west; used for giving directions and information from the ground or air in describing the fire (e.g., the west flank or east flank, not right flank or left flank).
label: cardinal directions

definition: A modified form of broadcast slash burning in which the greater accumulations of slash are fired and the fire is confined to these spots.
label: spot burning

definition: A fire treatment type. A prescribed fire to deliberately burn natural or modified concentrations (jackpots) of wildland fuels under specified environmental conditions, which allows the fire to be confined to a predetermined area and produces the fireline intensity and rate of spread required to attain planned resource Management Objectives.
label: jackpot burn

definition: An agent that extinguishes the flaming and glowing phases of combustion by direct application to the burning fuel.
label: suppressant

definition: Any combustible material, especially petroleum-based products and wildland fuels.
label: fuel

definition: Objects that are easily susceptible to damage from head and flame and can be easily damaged or destroyed by suppression action and/or during the evidence collection process. E.g., cigarette ash.
label: fragile fire cause objects

definition: Apparatus utilizing an air compressor and positive displacement pump coupled to the same engine, plumbed to a non-pressurized tank, for producing foam. The operation involves injecting compressed air into a liquid stream containing a suitable foaming agent.
label: Water Expansion Pumping System

definition: A point, line, or area, at which mass or energy is added to a system, either instantaneously or continuously. Examples of sources in the context of air pollution are as follows: a smoke stack is a point source; a freeway is a line source; field or slash burning are area sources.
label: source

definition: An area in which specified activities or entry are temporarily restricted to reduce risk of human-caused fires or to mitigate the risk to human health or safety by potential or on-going wildland fires.
label: closed area

definition: Tracking on-shift time of incident resources. Timekeeping is accomplished on the Crew Time Report, SF-261, or the Emergency Equipment Shift Ticket, OF-297.
label: timekeeping

definition: Direct attack around a fire in opposite directions by two or more attack units. Usually conducted from the fire's tail to head.
label: pincer action

definition: A number used to indicate relative (not actual) rate of spread.
label: spread index

definition: Setting fire to more than one strip of fuel and providing for the strips to burn together. Frequently done in burning out against a wind where inner strips are fired first to create drafts which pull flames and sparks away from the control line.
label: strip firing

definition: Chronological listing of the dates of fires documented in a designated area, the dates being corrected by crossdating. Size of the area must be specified.
label: master fire chronology

definition: A fire started by igniting the full perimeter of the intended burn area so that the ensuing fire fronts converge toward the center of the burn. Set around the outer perimeter of a resource to establish a protective black-line-buffer.
label: ring fire

definition: For ground observation purposes, a change of at least 45 degrees in the direction of a significant wind, which occurs in a relatively short time frame.
label: wind shift (ground observation)

definition: That area for which a particular fire protection organization has the primary responsibility for attacking an uncontrolled fire and for directing the suppression action. Such responsibility may develop through law, contract, or personal interest of the firefighting agent (e.g., a lumber operator). Several agencies or entities may have some basic responsibilities (e.g., private owner) without being known as the fire organization having direct protection responsibility.
label: protection area (primary responsibility)

definition: That area for which a particular fire protection organization has the primary responsibility for attacking an uncontrolled fire and for directing the suppression action. Such responsibility may develop through law, contract, or personal interest of the firefighting agent (e.g., a lumber operator). Several agencies or entities may have some basic responsibilities (e.g., private owner) without being known as the fire organization having direct protection responsibility.
label: direct protection area

definition: A device mounted inside or directly underneath an aircraft which can contain water or retardant for dropping onto a fire.
label: fixed tank

definition: Thickness of a liquid, the degree to which it resists flow.
label: viscosity

definition: Net attached to the cargo hook of a helicopter, used to carry cargo.
label: cargo net

definition: Numerical rating of the maximum effort required to contain all probable fires occurring within a rating area during the rating period.
label: Fire Load Index

definition: Checking the spread of fire at points of more rapid spread or special threat. Is usually the initial step in prompt control, with emphasis on first priorities.
label: hotspotting

definition: A species which is a part of the original fauna or flora of the area in question.
label: native species

definition: The midflame wind speed adjusted for the effect of slope on fire spread.
label: effective windspeed

definition: Plants and vegetation communities which have evolved adaptations such as a reliance on fire as a disturbance agent, protection as a species against the effects of wildland fire, or even a strengthening or enhancement by it.
label: fire dependent

definition: A tapered thread standard that is used for connecting various sizes of rigid pipe. This standard may be referred to as tapered iron pipe thread (TIPT), National pipe thread (NPT), iron pipe thread (IPT), or iron pipe standard thread (IPS). With tapered thread, the threads and pipe sealant perform the seal at the connection. This is opposed to straight thread connectors which use a gasket to form the seal.
label: Iron Pipe Thread

definition: All work and activities connected with control and fire-extinguishing operations, beginning with discovery and continuing until the fire is completely extinguished.
label: fire suppression

definition: Phase of combustion immediately following flaming combustion. Emissions are at twice that of the flaming combustion phase.
label: smoldering combustion phase

definition: Combined processes of dehydration, pyrolysis, solid oxidation, and scattered flaming combustion and glowing combustion, which occur after the flaming combustion phase of a fire; often characterized by large amounts of smoke consisting mainly of tars.
label: smoldering combustion

definition: Any situation in which it is highly dangerous to fight fire.
label: fire trap (situational)

definition: Contribution to human-caused risk made by a specific risk source; a function of the daily activity level assigned that risk source and the appropriate risk source ratio.
label: partial risk factor
definition extension: Part of the National Fire Danger Rating System (NFDRS).

definition: A person designated to detect and report fires from a vantage point.
label: lookout (fire)

definition: An area representative of the major fire problems on a protection unit. Base fuel model and slope class are chosen from the base area.
label: base area
definition extension: Part of the National Fire Danger Rating System (NFDRS).

definition: Fire crew member in the progressive method of line construction who cuts and clears away brush, small saplings, vines, and other obstructions in the path of the fireline; usually equipped with ax or brush hook, or pulaski.
label: line cutter

definition: Any source of heat, natural or human made, capable of igniting wildland fuels. Flaming or glowing fuel particles that can be carried naturally by wind, convection currents, or by gravity into unburned fuels.
label: firebrand

definition: The leading edge of a relatively warm air mass which moves in such a way that warm air replaces colder air that moves away from a region. Winds associated with warm frontal activity are usually light and mixing is limited. The atmosphere is relatively stable when compared to cold front activity.
label: warm front

definition: Blade attachment with long teeth specially suited to ripping and piling brush with minimum inclusion of soil.
label: brush blade

definition: A secondary pump on an engine in addition to the main pump. Usually of small capacity.
label: auxiliary pump

definition: The official delegation of authority to contracting officers and procurement officers establishing the dollar amount and type limits for acquisitions.
label: warrant

definition: Planned, measurable result desired from fire protection and use based on land management goals and objectives.
label: fire management objective

definition: An investigative technique that involves comparing same sized indicators within an indicator category at separate locations; looking for either differences or similarities in appearance.
label: compare and contrast (investigation)
definition extension: Includes the comparison of overall patterns and pattern clusters.

definition: The average maximum vertical extension of flames at the leading edge of the fire front. Occasional flashes that rise above the general level of flames are not considered. This distance is less than the flame length if flames are tilted due to wind or slope.
label: flame height

definition: A valve that permits flow of liquid through a hose or pipe in one direction but prevents a return flow. Uses include the prevention of backflow on uphill hose lays, loss of prime with centrifugal pumps and chemical contamination in fire chemical mixing systems.
label: check valve

definition: The period of combustion when a fire is spreading, usually accompanied by flaming combustion that releases heat to sustain the convection column.
label: advancing front combustion stage

definition: At a general level used to refer to the ability of a system (ecological or human) to resist damage and recover from a disturbance. In ecology, resiliency tends to refer to the ability of the system to return to the pre disturbance state with no assessment of whether that state is desirable or not. From a social perspective, resilience may reference ability to return to the original state but also can refer to the ability to recover to a state more likely to resist or recover quickly from future disturbance.
label: resiliency

definition: Specialized trailer on which is mounted a tank, fire pump, hose, and ancillary equipment.
label: tank trailer

definition: A scale drawing showing information about a fire scene.
label: diagram

definition: Filling pump with water when pump is taking water not under a pressure head. Necessary for centrifugal pumps.
label: priming

definition: The process of agitating foam solution and air within a confined space (usually a hose) that produces tiny, uniform bubbles - the length and type of hose determine the amount of scrubbing and, therefore, foam quality.
label: scrubbing

definition: Sum of lightning and human-caused risk values.
label: total risk
definition extension: Part of the National Fire Danger Rating System (NFDRS).
editorial note: GB - moved last line to business rule

definition: A mixture of chemicals designed to produce heat, light, gas, smoke or noise.
label: pyrotechnic

definition: Geographic points on the ground or specific points in time where an escalation or alternative of management actions is warranted. These points are defined and the management actions to be taken are clearly described in an approved Prescribed Fire Plan. Timely implementation of the actions when the fire reaches the action point is generally critical to successful accomplishment of the objectives.
label: management action points

definition: Pressure value obtained by the theoretical reduction or increase of station pressure to sea level. The average atmospheric pressure at sea level is 14.7 psi.
label: sea-level pressure

definition: A resource that includes a dozer, its transportation unit and a standard complement of personnel for its operation.
label: dozer company

definition: A legally enacted time during which burning activities are regulated by federal, state or local authority.
label: fire season (regulated)

definition: Pilot who is designated to be second-in-command of an aircraft during flight time.
label: second-in-command

definition: A firing technique consisting of treating an area with lines of fire set into the wind which burn outward at right angles to the wind.
label: flank fire

definition: Rate or spread and intensity of a fire usually falling somewhere in between advancing and backing with spread lateral to the main direction of fire travel.
label: lateral fire

definition: A unit of pressure equal to a force of 1,000 dynes per square centimeter. (A dyne is the force that would give a free mass of one gram an acceleration of one centimeter per second per second).
label: millibar

definition: Upper High, High Aloft, Upper Level Ridge: A circulation feature of the upper atmosphere where pressure, at a constant altitude, is higher than in the surrounding region. Winds blow clockwise around an upper level high. Air in an upper level high is usually subsiding. This results in comparatively warm dry air with light winds over a large area. An upper level high may exist without there being high pressure at the earth's surface.
label: upper level high
alternative label: upper level ridge, high aloft, upper high

definition: Lopping logging debris and spreading it more or less evenly over the ground.
label: lopping and scattering

definition: The maximum geographic limits of spread within which a wildland fire is allowed to spread.
label: Maximum Manageable Area

definition: Angle between the flame at the leading edge of the fire front and the ground surface, expressed in degrees.
label: flame angle

definition: The physical characteristics of the indicators that show the direction of fire spread, i.e., advancing, backing, or lateral.
label: directional vectors

definition: A fire burning in vegetation that is predominantly shrubs, brush, and scrub growth.
label: brush fire

definition: The individual factors which make up the ignition sequence; competent ignition source; the type and form of first fuel ignited; oxidant, plus the circumstances, actions, or natural events that allowed the factors to come together.
label: ignition factor

definition: On-incident costs and off-incident costs. On-incident costs include caterer, shower units, mobile commissary, cache supplies, and materials, etc. Off-incident costs include expanded dispatch, buying teams, administrative payment teams, cache personnel, area command, transportation to/from incident, etc.
label: support costs

definition: A line or set of lines, usually in 50' increments, used in external load operations that allow the helicopter to place loads in areas in which the helicopter could not safely land.
label: longline

definition: The spread of the fire from one location to another.
label: fire progression

definition: Pressure of the atmosphere at an assigned station location and elevation.
label: station pressure

definition: Portable air (not oxygen) tanks with regulators which allow firefighters to breathe while in toxic smoke conditions. Usually rated for 30 minutes of service. Used primarily on fires involving structures or hazardous materials.
label: Self-Contained Breathing Apparatus

definition: Portable air (not oxygen) tanks with regulators which allow firefighters to breathe while in toxic smoke conditions. Usually rated for 30 minutes of service. Used primarily on fires involving structures or hazardous materials.
label: air pack

definition: A simple filter mask for individual protection against smoke and fumes, recommended for use in fire suppression on wildfires only; not recommended for use on structure fires or fires involving most hazardous materials.
label: respirator

definition: The hours of a day (a daily tour-of-duty) and the days of an administrative workweek (a weekly tour-of-duty) that constitutes an employee's regularly scheduled administrative workweek.
label: tour-of-duty

definition: Facilities in which there is great likelihood of loss of life or property.
label: target hazard

definition: An internal area of an aircraft specifically designed to carry baggage or cargo.
label: cargo compartment

definition: Smoke from any authorized use of fire (e.g., locomotive, industrial operations, permitted debris burning).
label: legitimate smoke

definition: The highest value for dry bulb temperature measured at the observation site during the preceding 24-hour period.
label: maximum dry bulb temperature

definition: The lowest value for dry bulb temperature measured at the observation site during the preceding 24-hour period.
label: minimum dry bulb temperature

definition: Two or more firefighters stationed at a strategic location for initial action on fires. Duties are essentially the same as those of individual firefighters.
label: suppression crew

definition: Fire hose coupling with American National Standard (NH) threads.
label: standard coupling

definition: Allowable aircraft cabin load, in pounds, with full fuel and pilot in calm air at standard atmosphere.
label: internal payload

definition: Any nonfrontal line or narrow band of active thunderstorms extending across the horizon. It is of importance to fire behavior due to accompanying strong gusty winds and the possibility of such a line passing between regular weather observation stations without being reported.
label: squall line

definition: A geographical area between two or more jurisdictions into which those agencies would respond on initial attack.
label: mutual threat zone
alternative label: initial action zone, mutual response zone

definition: Belt-mounted case with pockets fitted for anemometer, compass, sling psychrometer, slide rule, water bottle, pencils, and book of weather report forms. Used to take weather observations to provide on-site conditions to the fire weather forecaster or fire behavior analyst. Observations include air temperature, wind speed and direction, and relative humidity.
label: belt weather kit

definition: Amount of heat required to raise 1 pound of water 1 degree Fahrenheit (from 59.50 to 60.50 F), measured at standard atmospheric pressure.
label: British Thermal Unit

definition: Activities undertaken in advance of fire occurrence to help ensure more effective fire suppression. Activities includes overall planning, recruitment and training of fire personnel, procurement and maintenance of firefighting equipment and supplies, fuel treatment and creating, maintaining, and improving a system of fuel breaks, roads, water sources, and control lines.
label: fire presuppression

definition: The helibase operational area that includes the touchdown pad, safety circle, hover lanes, and external cargo transport area.
label: deck

definition: The side of an object facing the oncoming fire.
label: exposed side

definition: The rapid oxidation of fuel in which heat and usually flame are produced. Combustion can be divided into four phases: preignition, flaming, smoldering, and glowing.
label: combustion

definition: A disturbance that transfers energy from one point to another point and may take the form of a deformation of pressure or temperature. In the atmosphere such disturbances may result in major storms or merely result in changes in cloud, wind and temperature conditions. Development of a wave on a front usually slows the advance of the front due to transfer of energy to the wave development and movement.
label: wave

definition: A fire management system that integrates the effects of selected fire danger factors into one or more qualitative or numerical indices of current protection needs.
label: fire danger rating

definition: A representation of the vegetative cover and fuel in a base area. Used in the calculation of fire danger rating.
label: base fuel model
definition extension: Part of the National Fire Danger Rating System (NFDRS).

definition: In prescribed burning, the initial line of fire, usually set as a backing fire along a barrier or control line, which serves to contain subsequent burning operations.
label: baseline

definition: The lowest temperature to which air can be cooled by evaporating water into it at a constant pressure when the heat required for evaporation is supplied by the cooling of the air. It is measured by the wet bulb thermometer, which usually employs wetted wicking on the bulb as a cooling (through evaporation) device.
label: wet-bulb temperature

definition: A tactical decision game that employs a three-dimensional terrain model made from sand and various props to provide a visual representation of the situation described in the tactical decision game.
label: Sand Table Exercise

definition: Specific, achievable, measurable, time-limited results to be achieved through land management practices, either through a description of a desired condition or the degree of desired change in an attribute.
label: objective (land management)

definition: High fire frequency over a short period of time in an administrative unit, usually overtaxing the normal initial attack capability of the unit.
label: multiple fire situation

definition: Any wildfire on rangeland.
label: range fire

definition: A branch of mathematics dealing with the collection, analysis, and interpretation of numerical data.
label: statistics

definition: The contractor furnishes all equipment operating supplies.
label: wet

definition: Average heights of foliage browning or bole blackening caused by a fire.
label: scorch height

definition: Establishment of a new plant from a seed that is a genetically distinct individual.
label: vegetative reproduction

definition: Incident-specific statements of direction necessary for the selection of strategy(s) and tactical activities of resources on an incident.
label: incident objectives

definition: Written agreement between agencies and/or jurisdictions in which they agree to assist one another upon request, by furnishing personnel and equipment.
label: mutual aid agreement

definition: To detach two pieces of hose by backing the swivel thread off the nipple thread.
label: break coupling

definition: Time needed under specified conditions for a fuel particle to lose about 63 percent of the difference between its initial moisture content and its equilibrium moisture content. If conditions remain unchanged, a fuel will reach 95 percent of its equilibrium moisture content after 4 timelag periods.
label: Timelag

definition: A plan developed by the Structure Protection Specialist that provides operational guidelines to suppression resources responsible for providing wildland fire structure protection.
label: structure protection plan

definition: A fire that has gained headway and built up heat in a structure so as to require greater cooling for extinguishment.
label: deep-seated fire (structure)

definition: In fire suppression terminology, a fire spreading from any fire originally ignited to clear land or burn rubbish, garbage, crop stubble, or meadows (excluding incendiary fires).
label: debris burning fire (suppression)

definition: Airspace of defined dimensions identified by an area on the surface of the earth within the flight of an aircraft, which is subject to restrictions (but not wholly prohibited).
label: restricted airspace

definition: A colorless, odorless, nonpoisonous gas, which results from fuel combustion and is normally a part of the ambient air.
label: Carbon Dioxide

definition: In aviation, the intended direction of horizontal flight.
label: course

Glossary Term: other training which supports development of knowledge and skills
definition: Courses defined as containing supplemental knowledge and skills not required for safe and tactical operations success on a wildfire.
label: other training which supports development of knowledge and skills

definition: A wire or metal guard used to keep debris from clogging pipe or other openings made for removing water; used in pumps and on suction hose to keep foreign material from clogging or damaging pumps.
label: strainer

definition: Time used by an airtanker or helitanker to reload and return to the fire.
label: turnaround time

definition: Shut-off nozzle that permits the nozzle operator to open or close the nozzle or adjust the pattern of the stream.
label: controlling nozzle

definition: General term for manifestations of convection in the atmosphere, alluding particularly to the development of convective clouds and resulting weather phenomena, such as showers, thunderstorms, squalls, hail, tornadoes, etc.
label: convective activity

definition: Partly decayed material, such as old wood, in which fire can smolder unless it is carefully mopped up and extinguished. A good receptor for firebrands when dry.
label: punky material

definition: An internet-based information system, providing national views of weather and fire potential, including national fire danger and weather maps and satellite-derived greenness maps.
label: Wildland Fire Assessment System

definition: Method of igniting prescribed fires in which ignition points are set individually at predetermined spacing with predetermined timing throughout the area to be burned.
label: grid ignition technique

definition: Any combination of single resources assembled for a particular tactical need, with common communications and a leader. A task force may be pre-established and sent to an incident, or formed at an incident.
label: task force

definition: The horizontal movement of air relative to the surface of the earth.
label: wind

definition: Pertaining to, or caused by mountains.
label: orographic

definition: Work performed by an individual employee in support of an incident while remaining at the employees duty station or other designated off-site location.
label: off-site/remote assignment

definition: A team that supports one or more incidents and is authorized to procure a wide range of services, supplies, and land and equipment rentals. In addition, the Buying Team Leader has the responsibility of coordinating property accountability with the Supply Unit Leader.
label: Buying Team

definition: Instructional aid in which the sides of a triangle are used to represent the three factors (oxygen, heat, fuel) necessary for combustion and flame production; removal of any of the three factors causes flame production to cease.
label: fire triangle

definition: Functional unit within the logistics section that is responsible for the emergency medical and occupational health care of incident personnel. Some incident management teams have placed this unit under safety.
label: Medical Unit

definition: Refers to the scheduled workweek of the employee (individual) at the home unit.
label: basic workweek

definition: An entity which oversees the preparedness activities for a particular ESF and coordinates with its primary and support agencies.
label: ESF Coordinator

definition: A product, tool, or IT application that has been designated as the trusted source for wildland fire data. This source may also create and update transactional data for use in other applications. There may be more than one IADS and it can change depending on business process complexity and life cycle. An IADS may be a compilation or subset of data from other authoritative sources. The DLM process ensures sources, limitations, currency, and attributes for the IADS are documented.
label: Interagency Authoritative Data Source

definition: A type of bleeder valve designed for installation at convenient points in hose lines to permit drawing off water for filling backpack pumps or other use without interfering with pump or nozzle operation.
label: water thief

definition: A satellite observation-derived value that is sensitive to vegetative growth, measured at 1.1 km (0.6 mile) spatial and 1 week temporal scales.
label: Normalized Difference Vegetation Index

definition: A turret-type nozzle usually mounted on an engine.
label: monitor

definition: The personnel responsible for fire suppression within a specified area.
label: fire suppression organization (area)

definition: Sum of constant danger and variable danger factors affecting the inception, spread, and resistance to control, and subsequent fire damage; often expressed as an index.
label: fire danger

definition: Burning of any fuel outdoors without the use of mechanical combustion enhancements.
label: open burning

definition: The temperature of the air measured in the shade 4-8 feet above the ground.
label: dry-bulb temperature, dry bulb temperature

definition: Depiction of the degree of departure from historical fire regimes, possibly resulting in alterations of key ecosystem components. These classes categorize and describe vegetation composition and structure conditions that currently exist inside the Fire Regime Groups. Based on the coarse-scale national data, they serve as generalized wildfire rankings. The risk of loss of key ecosystem components from wildfires increases from Condition Class 1 (lowest risk) to Condition Class 3 (highest risk).
label: condition class

definition: A qualitative measure classified into three classes describing the relative degree of departure from historical fire regimes, possibly resulting in alterations of key ecosystem components such as species composition, structural stage, stand age, canopy closure, and fuel loadings.
label: fire regime current condition class

definition: That part of the earth's lower atmosphere that is directly influenced by the presence of the earth's surface and responds to surface forcings such as fronts, friction, evapotranspiration and convective mixing.
label: planetary boundary layer

definition: Minor items of equipment and all expendable items assigned to an incident.
label: supplies

definition: All items for transport and delivery by aircraft.
label: air cargo

definition: Green leaves and succulents, uncured vegetation which bends and curls inwards towards the heat source due to desiccation.  One of the 11 NWCG categories of fire pattern indicator.
label: fire pattern indicator, curling
definition extension: Typically found on vegetation that is lower to the ground in areas of lower intensity burning.

definition: A model for predicting the average number of reportable human caused fires from a given ignition component value.
label: human-caused risk
definition extension: Part of the National Fire Danger Rating System (NFDRS).

definition: The deployment of fixed-wing or rotary aircraft on a wildland fire, to drop retardant or extinguishing agents, shuttle and deploy crews and supplies, or perform aerial reconnaissance of the overall fire situation.

definition: Item for storing drying fire hose.
label: hose rack

definition: An area of low pressure caused by intense heating of the earth's surface. High surface temperature causes air to expand and rise, resulting in low atmospheric pressure and induces a weak inflow of air at the surface. Air which rises in a heat low is very dry so clouds seldom form. Rising air above a heat low produces a warm upper level high and results in a net outflow of air aloft. Heat lows remain practically stationary over areas which produce them.
label: heat low

definition: A handheld electronic device that measures temperature, humidity, wind speed, and possibly other atmospheric variables, depending on brand and model.
label: pocket weather meter

definition: The protection of structures from the exterior, with no interior access or activity.
label: exterior fire protection

definition: Procedure by which the flow from two fire pumps is combined into one hose line.
label: parallel pumping

definition: A salary differential that compensates employees for exposure to hazards in the course of their duties.
label: hazard pay

definition: A person or group of persons who carries out patrol actions.
label: patrol (person)

definition: System of rating slash to indicate the treatment objective, whether or not burning is required to meet that objective, the fuel treatment necessary to achieve successful burning, and the time of year burning should occur.
label: burning priority rating

definition: The plan that each jurisdiction has and maintains for responding to appropriate hazards.
label: emergency operations plan

definition: Responsible for the collection, evaluation, and dissemination of tactical information related to the incident, and for the preparation and documentation of incident action plans. definition: A standardized on-scene emergency management concept specifically designed to allow its user(s) to adopt an integrated organizational structure equal to the complexity and demands of single or multiple incidents, without being hindered by jurisdictional boundaries.

definition: Time of actual work, ordered standby, or compensable travel with a specific start and ending time.
label: on-shift

definition: A facility established as the central point of contact for news media and interest parties to coordinate incident information activities at the scene of the incident. Public information officials from all participating federal, state, and local agencies should collocate at the JIC.

definition: Average height of the surface of the sea for all stages of the tide over a 19-year period. NOTE: when the abbreviation MSL is used in conjunction with a number of feet, it implies altitude above sea level (e.g., 1000 feet MSL).

definition: Literally, at one time. Thus, in meteorological usage, the weather conditions over a large area at a given point in time.
label: synoptic

definition: That organizational level with responsibility for a major functional area of the incident, such as operations, planning, logistics, finance/administration. The section is organizationally between branch and incident commander.

definition: Prescribed fire to control fungal infection (brown spot disease) of longleaf pine (Pinus palustris) in the "grass" (small seedling) stage.

definition: Burning in patches to prepare sites for group planting or sowing or to form a barrier to subsequent fires.

definition: The entity submitting a given incident report.

definition: Atmospheric conditions under which pollutants build up faster than the atmosphere can disperse them.

definition: That portion of the total fuel that would actually burn under various environmental conditions.

definition: Visibility impairment caused by the cumulative air pollutant emissions from numerous sources over a wide geographic area.

definition: A sufficient concentration of atmospheric aerosols to affect a visible attenuation of light and measurable reduction in visual range. The aerosol particle diameter is near the wavelength of visible light, optimizing the light scattering efficiency of the particles.

definition: Maximum wind speed during the previous 60 minutes.

definition: A fire that persists through the winter months until the beginning of fire season.

definition: The ICS title for an individual responsible for a task force, strike team, or functional unit.

definition: Foam with an expansion between 1:1 and 20:1.

definition: A dense fog (water droplets suspended in the atmosphere) that forms away from a fire site when surface smoke comprised of increased fine particulates and water vapor, combines with ambient air that is already prone to natural fog formation.
label: Smoke-Induced Fog
definition extension:
Under these conditions, smoke serves as a catalyst and induces surface fog formation, reducing visibility to a greater extent than smoke or fog individually. Smoke can induce fog in two ways.  
  1. Surface smoke contains additional water which is a byproduct of combustion. This excess water can induce fog or if present increase the density of existing fog.  
  1. Smoke contains particulate matter which may serve as condensation nuclei thus increasing the number of smaller fog droplets in smoke.  

In either case, SIF reduces visibility beyond that of the separate individual impacts of smoke or fog. SIF can occur anywhere within surface smoke plume but will usually be found in low-lying areas and drainages where ambient conditions most likely favor fog formation. Fog has formed when observed relative humidity is under 100% and thus, it forms more easily in the presence of smoke. SIF is also most likely to be found late at night or early in the morning when ambient conditions most likely favor fog formation.

definition: A series of modified strips or blocks tied together to form continuous strategically located fuel breaks around land units.

definition: A weather prediction specially prepared for use in wildland fire operations and prescribed fire.

definition: A combination hoe or cutting tool and rake, with or without removable blades.
