definition: Specified combinations of the same kind and type of resources, with common communications, and a leader.
label: strike team

definition: Elapsed time from containment or control of a fire until mopup is complete.
label: mop up time

definition: Model legislation recommended by the Fire Marshals' Association of North America and adopted by many states, regulating display of fireworks.
label: Model Fireworks Law

definition: A term used to describe the consistency and viscosity of low expansion foam as the combination of drain time and expansion.
label: foam type

definition: A not to scale drawing.
label: fire sketch
definition extension: Used to illustrate notes and refresh the fire investigator's memory.

definition: System of radio navigation in which any magnetic bearing relative to a special radio transmitter on the ground may be chosen and flown by an aircraft pilot.
label: VHF Omnidirectional Radio Range

definition: The initial decisions and actions taken in reaction to a reported incident.
label: initial response

definition: Principles and policies providing a common approach to wildland fire for federal agencies. The primary, interagency wildland fire policy document is the "Review and Update of the 1995 Federal Wildland Fire Management Policy" (January 2001). Implementation of that policy is through the "Guidance for Implementation of Federal Wildland Fire Management Policy" (February 2009).
label: federal fire policy

definition: A WIMS file that contains all the information defined for a weather station.
label: station catalog

definition: Two or more units of any one type working one in front of the other to accomplish a specific fire suppression job; the term can be used in connection with crews of firefighters, power pumps, bulldozers, etc.
label: tandem

definition: In meteorology, any chart or map on which data and analyses are presented that describe the state of the atmosphere over a large area at a given moment in time.
label: synoptic chart

definition: A method to document a fire scene using right angle measurements off of a base line.
label: right angle transect

definition: The side of an object opposite the oncoming fire and therefore shielded from the oncoming fire by the object itself.
label: protected side

definition: Act of clearing brush and other material from around the base of trees and where trees are to be bucked, prior to falling or bucking, as protection against saw kickback and to provide safe footing.
label: swampout

definition: Air which has a high moisture content and the temperature characteristics of an ocean surface due to extensive exposure to that surface. An intrusion of marine air will moderate fire conditions. Absence of marine air in coastal areas may lead to more severe fire danger.
label: marine air

definition: The state of the combined factors of the environment that affect fire behavior in a specified fuel type.
label: burning conditions
editorial note: JK-checked.  In the definition, should it be "affect" or "effect"?

definition: The study of the effects of fire on living organisms and their environment.
label: fire ecology

definition: Geographic areas designed by the Clean Air Act subject to the most stringent restrictions on allowable increment of air quality deterioration. Class I areas include Forest Service wildernesses and nation memorial parks over 5,000 acres, National Parks exceeding 6,000 acres, international parks, as well as other designated lands.
label: Class I Areas (air quality)

definition: Saving a life from fire or accident; removing a victim from an untenable or unhealthy atmosphere.
label: rescue

definition: Smoke that has drifted from its point of origin and is no longer dominated by convective motion. May give false impression of a fire in the general area where the smoke has drifted.
label: drift smoke

definition: A code reflecting the moisture content of the foliage and small twigs [less than 1/4 inch (0.6 cm)] of living woody plants.
label: woody vegetation condition
definition extension: Part of the National Fire Danger Rating System (NFDRS).

definition: Layer through which temperature remains constant with elevation.
label: isothermal layer

definition: A classification of fire regimes into a discrete number of categories based on frequency and severity. The national, coarse-scale classification of fire regime groups commonly used includes five groups: I - frequent (0-35 years), low severity; II - frequent (0-35 years), stand replacement severity; III - 35-100+ years, mixed severity; IV - 35-100+ years, stand replacement severity; and V - 200+ years, stand replacement severity.
label: fire regime groups

definition: Description of the patterns of fire occurrences, frequency, size, severity, and sometimes vegetation and fire effects as well, in a given area or ecosystem. A fire regime is a generalization based on fire histories at individual sites. Fire regimes can often be described as cycles because some parts of the histories usually get repeated, and the repetitions can be counted and measured, such as fire return interval.
label: fire regime

definition: The documented location where a photograph was taken.
label: photo point

definition: The ratio of live crown to tree height.
label: crown ratio

definition: Maximum distance at which a given object can just be seen by an observer with normal vision.
label: visual range

definition: The fuels, weather and topographical conditions of a specific fire scene or area of the fire scene at the time of fire passage.
label: fire behavior context

definition: Fixed-wing aircraft certified by FAA as being capable of transport and delivery of fire retardant solutions.
label: airtanker

definition: Centrifugal pump with a single impeller.
label: single stage pump

definition: Non-compensable time, e.g., eating, sleeping or other activities of a personal nature.
label: off-shift

definition: The number assigned to an incident. This number follows a standard format where the first two letters indicate the state, the next letters are the incident agency, and the last six digits are agency assigned.
label: incident order number

definition: The time between the end of evening civil twilight and the beginning of morning civil twilight, as published in the American Air Almanac, converted to local time.
label: night (aviation)

definition: Analysis of factors which influence suppression of an escaped fire from which a plan of attack will be developed; includes development of alternative strategies of fire suppression and net effect of each.
label: situation analysis

definition: Device which uses the exhaust gas flow of an engine for priming a centrifugal pump.
label: exhaust primer

definition: A loose limb, top, or piece of bark lodged in a tree, which may fall on anyone working beneath it.
label: widow-maker

definition: A meteorological station specially equipped to measure weather elements that have an important effect on fire behavior.
label: fire weather station

definition: A colored flare designed as a railway warning device, widely used to ignite backfires and other prescribed fires.
label: fusee

definition: In hydraulics, the pressure loss caused by raising water through hose or pipe to a higher elevation (roughly equal to one psi for every two-foot increase in elevation above the pump) (11.3 kPa per meter).
label: elevation loss

definition: According to the American Meteorological Society, in the Northern Hemisphere, a wind that rotates in the counterclockwise direction with increasing height. In fire management usage, in the Northern Hemisphere, a wind that rotates in the counterclockwise direction over a given time period (normally a few hours).
label: backing wind

definition: A command philosophy that encourages leaders to work together to find common ground and act in the best interest of those responding to the incident, the public, and the resources that are threatened.
label: unity of effort

definition: In the 1978 version of NFDRS, the herbaceous stage when cold temperatures kill herbaceous plants and force woody fuels into dormancy.
label: frozen

definition: The characterization of fire occurrence in an area, described in terms of total number of fires and acres per year; and number of fires by time, size, cause, fire-day, large fire-day, and multiple fire-day.
label: fire business

definition: A level of certainty corresponding to being more likely true than not.
label: probable
definition extension: At this level of certainty, the likelihood of the hypothesis being true is greater than 50 percent.

definition: An agreement written at an incident using an EERA, OF-294. The duration is for the length of the incident only.
label: Emergency Equipment Rental Agreement

definition: The chance that a firebrand will cause an ignition when it lands on receptive fuels.
label: probability of ignition

definition: Groupings of governmental and certain private sector capabilities and functions into an organizational structure to provide support, resources, program implementation, and services that are most likely needed to support disaster response operations.
label: Emergency Support Function

definition: An accumulation of highly combustible material, rendering firefighting dangerous.
label: fire trap (material accumulation)

definition: The amount of heat flowing through a given area in a given time, usually expressed as calories/square centimeter/second.
label: radiant heat flux

definition: Classification for a fire not originating in a building, but which ignites building(s). A fire originating in one building and spreading to another is classified under the original cause of fire.
label: exposure fire

definition: Someone with sufficient skill, knowledge, or experience in a given field so as to be capable of drawing inferences or reaching conclusions or opinions that an average person would not be competent to reach. The expert's opinion testimony should aim the judge or jury in their understanding of the fact at issue.
label: expert witness

definition: An organization established to: 1) oversee the management of multiple incidents that are each being handled by an incident management team (IMT) organization; or 2) to oversee the management of a very large incident that has multiple IMTs assigned to it. Area Command has the responsibility to set overall strategy and priorities, allocate critical resources based on priorities, ensure that incidents are properly managed, and that objectives are met and strategies followed.
label: area command

definition: Fuel breaks built in timbered areas where the trees on the break are thinned and pruned to reduce the fire potential yet retain enough crown canopy to make a less favorable microclimate for surface fires.
label: shaded fuel break

definition: A situation where personnel are unexpectedly caught in a fire behavior-related, life-threatening position where planned escape routes or safety zones are absent, inadequate, or compromised. An entrapment may or may not include deployment of a fire shelter for its intended purpose. These situations may or may not result in injury. They include "near misses."
label: entrapment

definition: Lightweight portable pump developed for transport by helicopter.
label: helipumper

definition: The accumulation of living and dead ground and understory vegetation, especially grasses, forest litter, and draped dead needles, sometimes with addition of underbrush such as palmetto, gallberry, and wax myrtle. Most often used for southern pine types.
label: rough

definition: Sky cover that prevents detection of higher clouds or the sky above it.
label: dense sky cover

definition: Fire originating in and burning any part or all of any building, shelter, or other structure.
label: structure fire

definition: Soil layers below the predominantly organic horizons; soil with little combustible material.
label: mineral soil

definition: Hose commonly of cotton, linen, or synthetic fiber construction without rubber tube or lining, often used for wildfires because of its light weight and self protecting (weeping) characteristics; such hose is attached to first-aid standpipes in buildings. At a specified flow, friction loss in unlined hose of a stated diameter is about twice that of lined fire hose.
label: unlined fire hose

definition: A structured review or de-brief process of an event, focused on performance standards, that enables participants to discover for themselves what happened, why it happened, and how to sustain strengths and improve on weaknesses. After action reviews, informal or formal, follow the same general format, involve the exchange of ideas and observations, and focus on improving performance.
label: After Action Review

definition: A force created by the rapid acceleration or deceleration of water, commonly created by opening or closing a valve too quickly. Pressures developed in a water hammer, proportional to the mass multiplied by the square of the velocity, can damage a pipe or hose.
label: water hammer

definition: A fire burning with a size and intensity such that its behavior is determined by interaction between its own convection column and weather conditions above the surface.
label: large fire (behavior)

definition: Apparatus used to detect heat.
label: heat probe

definition: The protection of homes or other structures from an active wildland fire.
label: structural fire protection

definition: Result of chemical reaction between a metal and its environment (i.e., air, water, and impurities in same).
label: corrosion

definition: Identifiable human activity that historically has been a major cause of wildfires on a protection unit; one of the eight general causes listed on the standard fire report.
label: risk source
editorial note: gb - does this definition need to be revisited with the revision of the fire cause standard?

definition: Permanently installed supply private fire pumps which depend upon suction sources.
label: dry hydrant (suction source)

definition: An offender who sets three or more fires at the same location during a limited period of time.
label: mass arsonist

definition: Process of extinguishing fire by the use of an agent that interrupts the chemical reactions in the combustion process.
label: inhibition

definition: Total allowable weight of a loaded aircraft for takeoff or landing, adjusted for altitude differences.
label: gross weight

definition: The process of developing and interpreting goals and objectives necessary to guide wildland fire management actions.
label: fire planning
definition extension: Process includes analysis and display of data and application of Laws, Policies, and Environmental Planning documents to wildland fire.

definition: Individual lightning or railroad fires, especially when several are started within a short time.
label: set (individual)

definition: Airport not having an approved agency with radio communications to direct aircraft take-offs and landings.
label: uncontrolled airport

definition: A work order issued by FEMA, with or without reimbursement, which directs another federal agency to utilize its authorities and the resources granted to it under federal law in support of state, local, tribal, and territorial government assistance.
label: mission assignment

definition: Pilot responsible for the operation and safety of an aircraft during flight time.
label: pilot-in-command

definition: Oral or written statement tending to link its maker to involvement in a particular crime.
label: admission

definition: The dispatch center actively supporting an incident and the resources assigned or a resource who is temporarily transferred for official action i.e. details, temporary duty station, etc.
label: dispatch center (current)
definition extension: The current dispatch center for an incident may change to support other centers, units or agencies. The current dispatch center may be the same as the incident dispatch center or home dispatch center or may be different. Current dispatch center for tactical aviation resources is directly associated with the resource independent of an incident.

definition: A pressure-controlled device which bypasses water at a fire pump to prevent excessive pressures when a nozzle is shut down.
label: relief valve

definition: An organized group of firefighters under the leadership of a crew boss or other designated official.
label: crew

definition: A mass of gas undergoing rapid combustion, generally accompanied by evolution of sensible heat and incandescence.
label: flame (scientific)

definition: Thermal or chemical decomposition of fuel at an elevated temperature. This is the pre-combustion stage of burning during which distillation and pyrolysis predominate. Heat energy is absorbed by the fuel which, in turn, gives off water vapor and flammable tars, pitches, and gases. These ignite when mixed with oxygen to initiate the flaming combustion phase.
label: preignition combustion phase

definition: A geographic area of relatively homogenous climate, fuels and topography, tens of thousands of acres in size, within which the fire danger can be assumed to be uniform. The basic on-the-ground unit for which unique fire management decisions are made based on fire danger ratings. Weather is represented by one or more NFDRS weather stations.
label: fire danger rating area

definition: Species of vegetation that establish on a burned (or otherwise denuded) site from seed.
label: colonizer

definition: A formal investigation team that is organized with the purpose of conducting an accident investigation for an occurred serious accident. The team is given full authorization to conduct the investigation from involved agencies through letter of delegation.
label: Serious Accident Investigation Team

definition: The larger area where the fire first established itself and is identified by an analysis of the fire behavior context, macroscale fire pattern indicators, and witness statements.
label: General Origin Area

definition: Chemical that inhibits combustion primarily through chemical reactions between products of combustion and the applied chemicals, even after the water component has evaporated. Other chemical effects also may be achieved, such as film-forming and intumescence.
label: long-term fire retardant

definition: A set of decisions that establish management direction for land within an administrative area; an assimilation of land-use-plan-level decisions developed through the planning process regardless of the scale at which the decisions were developed.
label: land use plan

definition: An organized, phased, and supervised withdrawal, dispersal, or removal of civilians from dangerous or potentially dangerous areas, and their reception and care in safe areas.
label: evacuation

definition: Water soluble substance that reduces frictional drag of solutions and dampens turbulent flow while being pumped through pipe or hose.
label: Friction Reducing Agent

definition: Individual responsible for incident agency business management functions, such as personnel, procurement, fiscal, etc.
label: Administrative Representative

definition:
As to size of wildfire:
  • Class A - one-fourth acre or less;
  • Class B - more than one-fourth acre, but less than 10 acres;
  • Class C - 10 acres or more, but less than 100 acres;
  • Class D - 100 acres or more, but less than 300 acres;
  • Class E - 300 acres or more, but less than 1,000 acres;
  • Class F - 1,000 acres or more, but less than 5,000 acres;
  • Class G - 5,000 acres or more.
label: size class of fire

definition: An aggressive action to put the fire out by the first resources to arrive, consistent with firefighter and public safety and values to be protected.
label: Initial Attack

definition: An airborne dust, fume, gas, mist, odor, smoke, vapor, soot, pollen, carbon, acid or particulate matter or any combination thereof.
label: air contaminant

definition: The general term referring to the undesirable addition of substances (gases, liquids, or solid particles) to the atmosphere that are foreign to the natural atmosphere or are present in quantities exceeding natural concentrations.
label: air pollution

definition: Release of resources from an incident in strict accordance with a detailed plan approved by the incident commander.
label: demobilization

definition: The apparatus and techniques used to mix concentrate with water to make solution, pump and mix air and solution to make foam, and transport and apply foam. (Systems defined here include compressed air foam and nozzle aspirated.)
label: foam systems

definition: A constructed object, usually a free-standing building above ground.
label: structure (constructive)

definition: Ignition of several individual fires throughout an area, either simultaneously or in rapid succession, and so spaced that they add to and influence the main body of the fire to produce a hot, fast-spreading fire condition.
label: area ignition

definition: A dry chemical product which is mixed with water to form a fire retardant slurry.
label: Gum Thickened Sulphate

definition: Load carried inside the fuselage structure of an aircraft.
label: internal load

definition: Adjective class representing the degree to which the sky is obscured by clouds. In weather forecast terminology, expected cloud cover of about 0.7 or more warrants use of this term. In the National Fire Danger Rating System, 0.6 or more cloud cover is termed "cloudy."
label: cloudy

definition: Water or fire retardant projected directly from the nozzle (as contrasted with a fog or spray cone), provided by a solid stream orifice or by adjusting a fog jet into a straight stream pattern.
label: straight stream

definition: Brief meetings held at the beginning, during, or end of an operational period to discuss new work assignments, new work methods, changes in plans, use of tools and equipment, and recognition and protection against work hazards that may be encountered.
label: tailgate safety session

definition: The composition of air with respect to quantities of pollution therein; used most frequently in connection with "standards" of maximum acceptable pollutant concentrations. Used instead of "air pollution" when referring to programs.
label: air quality

definition: Spacing between fuel particles.
label: compactness
editorial note: JK-checked.  Related term "bulk density" not listed in NWCG, but is listed in EDG.  Need to delete if don't want.

definition: A standing dead tree or part of a dead tree from which at least the leaves and smaller branches have fallen. Often known as a stub, if less than 20 feet tall.
label: snag

definition: An organization needed to support an incident which expands along with the Incident Command System.
label: expanded dispatch

definition: Firebrands, flaming sparks, or embers are carried by surface winds, starting new fires beyond the zone of direct ignition by the main fire. The range of such spotting is usually less than 1/4 mile.
label: short-range spotting

definition: Climate that is characteristic of the interior of a land mass of continental size, marked by large annual diurnal and day-to-day ranges of temperature, low relative humidity and irregular precipitation.
label: continental climate

definition: A valve in which fluid flow is controlled by a ball with a hole drilled through it. In one position, fluid flows through the hole. When the valve is turned 90 degrees (1/4 turn) the hole is perpendicular to the flow and the ball stops the flow. Intermediate valve positions can be used to adjust the flow.
label: ball valve

definition: An intermediary pump for supplying additional lift in pumping water uphill past the capacity of the first pump.
label: booster pump

definition: Term used in resource planning/following to estimate time of arrival at a point.
label: Estimated Time of Arrival

definition: Externally mounted rack for transporting supplies or cargo aboard a helicopter.
label: cargo rack

definition: Qualified firefighters, together with their equipment and material, used to suppress wildland fires.
label: firefighting forces

definition: The government furnishes all operating supplies after the equipment arrives at the incident.
label: dry

definition: A hose lay consisting of consecutively coupled lengths of hose without laterals. The lay is extended by inserting additional lengths of hose in the line between pumps and nozzle.
label: simple hose lay

definition: Fuels which provide vertical continuity between strata, thereby allowing fire to carry from surface fuels into the crowns of trees or shrubs with relative ease. They help initiate and assure the continuation of crowning.
label: ladder fuels

definition: The planned number of years between prescribed fires on a specified area.
label: burning rotation

definition: An area in which development is essentially non-existent, except for roads, railroads, powerlines, and similar transportation facilities. Structures, if any, are widely scattered.
label: wildland

definition: A number related to the potential number of firebrands to which a given area will be exposed during the rating day.
label: fire risk (potential)
definition extension: Part of the National Fire Danger Rating System (NFDRS).

definition: An identifiable association of fuel elements of distinctive species, form, size, arrangement, or other characteristics that will cause a predictable rate of spread or resistance to control under specified weather conditions.
label: fuel type

definition: Any fire crew composed of prison inmates or wards.
label: inmate crew

definition: The number of years between two successive fire events for a given area; also referred to as fire-free interval or fire-return interval.
label: fire interval

definition: Method of upper-air observation consisting of an evaluation of the wind speed and wind direction, temperature, pressure, and relative humidity aloft by means of a balloon-borne radiosonde tracked by a radar or radio direction-finder.
label: rawinsonde

definition: Bearing by true north rather than magnetic north.
label: true bearing

definition: Standby crew in an area of expected high fire occurrence, generally on a day of critical fire weather.
label: spike-out

definition: Amount of clouds and/or other obscuring phenomena that are detectable from the point of observation.
label: sky cover

definition: An appropriate management response to wildfire or prescribed fire that results in curtailment of fire spread and eliminates all identified threats from the particular fire.
label: wildfire suppression

definition: Those agency costs that are billable and/or reimbursable as defined by the master or individual cost share agreement.
label: billable/reimbursable costs
editorial note: JK-checked.  Consider splitting these into 2 separate terms:  "billable costs" and "reimbursable costs".  The "/" forward slash may not play well with other programs.

definition: Fire prevention specialist or arson investigator.
label: fire inspector

definition: The chance of fire starting as determined by the presence and activity of causative agents.
label: risk (ignition)

definition: A short term for "permanently frozen ground"; any part of the earth's crust, bedrock, or soil mantle that remains below 32 F (0 C) continuously for a number of years.
label: permafrost

definition: The expected amount of annual rainfall. Average annual precipitation is an important component to determining the Keech-Bryam Drought Index (KBDI).
label: average annual precipitation

definition: Any ground vehicle providing specified levels of pumping, water, and hose capacity but with less than the specified level of personnel.
label: engine

definition: Personnel and equipment used to control a fire.
label: control force

definition: Arsonist, especially a repetitive firesetter.
label: fire bug

definition: Fire suppression activities by other than regular fire suppression organizations or a fire cooperator.
label: independent action

definition: A widespread rain that over an extended period of time significantly reduces fire danger. One-tenth of an inch may be sufficient to reduce fire danger in grass fuel models. One half inch may be necessary for timber fuels under closed canopies.
label: wetting rain

definition: The net amount of heat that would be given off if fuel burns when it is absolutely dry, noted as Btu per pound of fuel.
label: heat content

definition: Large single fire pattern indicator or overall patterns of indicators that are readily visible from a distance.
label: macroscale fire pattern indicator

definition: Any fireline constructed at a distance from the fire perimeter concurrently with or after a line already constructed on or near to the perimeter of the fire. Generally constructed as an insurance measure in case the fire escapes control by the primary line.
label: secondary line

definition: Highest altitude above sea level at which a helicopter can hover at maximum computed gross weight. It is generally specified whether the quoted hover ceiling refers to hovering in ground effect (HIGE) or hovering out of ground effect (HOGE).
label: hover ceiling

definition: A plan developed in the collaborative framework established by the Wildland Fire Leadership Council and agreed to by state, tribal, and local government, local fire department, other stakeholders and federal land management agencies managing land in the vicinity of the planning area. A Community Wildfire Protection Plan (CWPP) identifies and prioritizes areas for hazardous fuel reduction treatments and recommends the types and methods of treatment on Federal and non-Federal land that will protect one or more at-risk communities and essential infrastructure and recommends measures to reduce structural ignitability throughout the at-risk community. A CWPP may address issues such as wildfire response, hazard mitigation, community preparedness, or structure protection - or all of the above.
label: Community Wildfire Protection Plan

definition: The appropriate ratio of liquid foam concentrate to water recommended by the chemical manufacturer for each class of fire, usually expressed as a percent (such as 0.5%).
label: use level

definition: Part of a population; that portion of the population that is measured.
label: sample

definition: Cards filled out with essential information for each resource they represent. The cards are color-coded to represent different types of resources.
label: T-card

definition: General large-scale climate of a large area or country as distinguished from smaller scale mesoclimate and microclimate.
label: macroclimate

definition:
• Three guiding values that should be the basis for the decisions that leaders make. The three values are:
    1. Duty  How a leader values their job. Duty begins with everything required by law and policy, but is much more than that. A leader commits to excellence in all aspects of their professional responsibility so that when the job is done they can look back and say, "I couldn't have given any more".
    2. Respect How a leader values their co-workers. Respect for the individual forms the very basis for the rule of law in America. This value reminds leaders that those who follow are their greatest resource. Not all followers will succeed equally, but they all deserve respect.
    3. Integrity How a leader values himself or herself. An individual cannot be in charge of others unless they are in charge of their own actions. People of integrity separate what is right from what is wrong and act according to what they know is right, even at personal cost.
label: wildland fire leadership values

definition:
Eleven principles describing tangible behaviors that reflect and demonstrate the wildland fire leadership values. The eleven principles are:
  1. Be proficient in your job.
  2. Make sound and timely decisions.
  3. Ensure tasks are understood, supervised, and accomplished.
  4. Develop your subordinates for the future.
  5. Know your subordinates and look out for their well-being.
  6. Keep your subordinates informed.
  7. Build the team.
  8. Employ your subordinates in accordance with their capabilities.
  9. Know yourself and seek improvement.
  10. Seek responsibility and accept responsibility for your actions.
  11. Set the example.
label: wildland fire leadership principles

definition: Lift that is gained when a helicopter translates from a hover into forward flight; additional lift increases with increasing airspeed and is derived by the rotor system moving into undisturbed air.
label: translational lift

definition: A burning compound or metal used to produce intense heat or flame, like a bomb.
label: incendiary

definition: Commonly accepted term for short length of large diameter soft hose used to connect a structural or wildland engine with a hydrant. No vacuum is involved because the hose is useful only when the engine receives water at a rate of flow in excess of the demand of the pump.
label: soft suction

definition: Any wildfire on which suppression action has not reached an extensive mop up stage.
label: going fire

definition: Characteristics fire cone-shaped pattern left by a fire on a wall, at or near its point of origin.
label: v pattern

definition: A prescribed fire set to evaluate such things as fire behavior, fire effects, detection performance, or control measures.
label: test fire

definition: The expansion or spreading out of a horizontal wind field. Generally associated with high pressure and light winds.
label: divergence

definition: Rate of decrease of temperature with increasing height of an air parcel lifted at saturation via adiabatic process through an atmosphere in hydrostatic equilibrium. Rate varies according to the amount of water vapor in the parcel and is usually between 2.0 and 5.0 degrees F per 1000 feet (3.6 and 9.2 degrees C per 1000 meters).
label: moist adiabatic lapse rate

definition: The mass of particulate matter produced per unit mass of fuel consumed (pounds per ton, grams per kilogram).
label: Emission Factor

definition: The smoldering zone behind the zone of an advancing fire front.
label: residual combustion stage

definition: Pressure due to elevation of water. Equals 0.433 pounds per square inch (PSI) per foot of elevation. (Approximately 0.5 PSI is required to lift water 1 foot in elevation)
label: head pressure

definition: Area of change between advancing, lateral, and backing vectors.
label: transition zone

definition: One of five categories used to describe the topography of a fire danger rating area.
label: slope class

definition: A collapsible bucket slung below a helicopter. Used to dip water from a variety of sources for fire suppression.
label: Bambi Bucket

definition: Chance that a firebrand will cause an ignition when it lands on receptive fuels.
label: ignition probability

definition: An injury or illness/disease caused by a person or object under circumstances that indicate there may be a legal liability on a party other than the federal or state government.
label: third-party case
editorial note: GB - moved last line of definition to business rule

definition: Increasing coupling used on hose, pump, or nozzles to permit connection of a larger size of hose.
label: increaser

definition: Specific instructions clearly spelling out what is expected of an individual every time they perform a given task. A standard operational procedure can be used as a performance standard for tasks that are routinely done in the operational environment.
label: Standard Operational Procedure

definition: Specific instructions clearly spelling out what is expected of an individual every time they perform a given task. A standard operating procedure can be used as a performance standard for tasks that are routinely done in the operational environment.
label: Standard Operating Procedure

definition: A turbulent altocumulus-type cloud formation found in the lee of some large mountain barriers. The air in the cloud rotates around an axis parallel to the range. Also sometimes refers to part of the cloud base along the leading edge of a cumulonimbus cloud; it is formed by rolling action in the wind shear region between cool downdrafts within the cloud and warm updrafts outside the cloud.
label: roll cloud

definition: A detailed prescription for treating a specified burning block with fire.
label: block plan

definition: Drawing water from static sources such as a lake, pond, cistern, river, etc. into a pump which is above the level of the water supply. This is done by removing the air from the pump and allowing atmospheric pressure [14.7 psi (101 kPa) at sea level] to push water through a noncollapsible suction hose into the pump.
label: draft

definition: Total amount of heat released per unit area as the flaming front of the fire passes, expressed as Btu/square foot; a measure of the total amount of heat released in flames.
label: heat per unit area

definition: The agency having land and resource management responsibility for a specific geographical or functional area as provided by federal, state or local law.
label: jurisdictional agency

definition: A case study of a previous incident that is conducted on the actual physical site where the incident occurred. A staff ride is an experiential learning method that involves three distinct parts: a preliminary study, a site visit, and a post-visit integration session.
label: staff ride

definition: The result of nitric oxide combining with oxygen in the atmosphere. A major component of photochemical smog.
label: Nitrogen Dioxide

definition: A parachute designed and rigged for dropping equipment and supplies from an aircraft.
label: cargo chute

definition: In a discussion of fire retardant slurries, deterioration of viscosity.
label: degradation

definition: A small ditch often constructed below a fire on sloping ground (undercut or underslung line) to catch rolling material.
label: trench

definition: The total heat energy released during combustion, usually published as units of heat energy produced per unit mass of ovendry fuel consumed.
label: heat value

definition: A condition of poor contaminant dispersion which may result in concentrations considered potentially harmful to health or welfare. Episodes may also occur during periods of fairly good dispersion if the source of air contaminants is extremely large.
label: episode (pollution)

definition: Combustible material, such as rolled rag, blankets and newspapers, or flammable liquid, used to spread fire from one area to others; usually used in conjunction with an incendiary device.
label: trailer

definition: Computed gross weight for an aircraft, obtained from the appropriate performance chart, which is the maximum gross weight appropriate to the applicable circumstance of configuration and/or environmental conditions.
label: maximum computed gross weight

definition: A federal law enacted to ensure that air quality standards are attained and maintained. Initially passed by Congress in 1963, it has been amended several times.
label: Clean Air Act

definition: An elongated area of relatively low atmospheric pressure, usually extending from the center of a low pressure system.
label: trough

definition: A helicopter equipped with a fixed tank, Airtanker Board certified, capable of delivering a minimum of 1,100 gallons of water, foam, or retardant.
label: helitanker

definition: Velocity of an aircraft in its flight path relative to the air through which it is moving.
label: true airspeed

definition: Wind directions used to calculate fire behavior.
label: wind vectors

definition: In the 1978 version of NFDRS, the herbaceous stage approximately 30 days prior to green-up.
label: pre-green

definition: Development of new aboveground plants from surviving plant parts, such as by sprouting from a root crown or rhizomes. Even if plants form their own root system, they are still genetically the same as the parent plant.
label: vegetative regeneration

definition: A causative agent.
label: fire risk (agent)

definition: A series of lines of fire ignited near and up wind (or downslope) of a firebreak or backing fire so they burn with the wind (or upslope) toward the firebreak or backing fire.
label: strip-head fire

definition: The rate of heat release per unit time per unit length of fire front. Numerically, it is the product of the heat yield, the quantity of fuel consumed in the fire front, and the rate of spread.
label: fireline intensity (rate)

definition: Act of connecting a control line to another fireline or an intended firebreak.
label: tie-in

definition: Fire scar in a tree resulting from fire injury to the cambium without destruction of the overlying bark and therefore not readily discernible.
label: hidden fire scar

definition: The parts of a fire's perimeter that are roughly parallel to the main direction of spread.
label: flanks of a fire (spread)

definition: Planned and identified fire suppression personnel and equipment that mitigate possible but unlikely events that exceed or are expected to exceed holding resource capabilities.
label: contingency resources

definition: Small gasoline-driven pump that can be carried to a water source by one or two firefighters or other conveyance over difficult terrain.
label: portable pump

definition: A statement issued by a National Weather Service forecast office when atmospheric conditions are stable enough such that the potential exists for air pollutants to accumulate in a given area. The statement is initially issued when conditions are expected to last for at least 36 hours.
label: Air Stagnation Advisory

definition: The fraction of a fuel bed occupied by fuels, or the fuel volume divided by bed volume.
label: packing ratio

definition: Unit of wildland delineated by logical and strategic topographic features for preattack planning.
label: preattack block

definition: Stage of growth or degree of flammability of vegetation that forms part of a fuel complex. Herbaceous stage is at times used when referring to herbaceous vegetation alone. In grass areas minimum qualitative distinctions for stages of annual growth are usually green, curing, and dry or cured.
label: condition of vegetation

definition: A device used to determine the burning index for different combinations of burning index factors.
label: burning index meter

definition: Refers to type 1 (national interagency support cache), type 2 (national interagency support cache satellite), and type 3 (local interagency support cache). Caches may consist of a pre-determined complement of tools, equipment and/or supplies stored in a designated location, available for incident use.
label: incident support cache

definition: The intermingling of plant communities and their successional stages in such a manner as to give the impression of an interwoven design.
label: mosaic

definition: The results of those factors in fire danger affecting long-term planning; involves consideration of past records and conditions and probable future trends.
label: long-term fire danger

definition: Prescribed burning activity where fire is applied generally to most or all of an area within well defined boundaries for reduction of fuel hazard, as a resource management treatment, or both.
label: broadcast burning

definition: A heavy cutting tool designed primarily to cut brush at the base of the stem. Used in much the same way as an axe and having a wide blade, generally curved to protect the blade from being dulled by rocks.
label: brush hook

definition: The portion of a chemical mixture or compound which furnishes oxygen for burning a fuel or propellant, creating an oxide.
label: oxidizer

definition: A fire in the crowns of trees in which trees or groups of trees torch, ignited by the passing front of the fire. The torching trees reinforce the spread rate, but these fires are not basically different from surface fires.
label: passive crown fire

definition: Weak or missed area in a retardant drop or in a fireline.
label: gap

definition: Specially trained and equipped fire crew for initial attack on a fire.
label: initial attack crew

definition: A substance or material which has been determined by the Secretary of Transportation to be capable of posing an unreasonable risk to health, safety, and property when transported in commerce and which has been so designated.
label: hazardous materials (transported)

definition: A statement issued by an Air Quality Regulatory Agency due to high measured concentrations of pollutants. The alert remains in effect until monitoring shows a decrease in pollutant levels. Should conditions worsen, air pollution warnings and emergencies may be issued. At each stage (alert, warning and emergency) additional emission restrictions are put into effect so as to not intensify the situation. Essentially, at the emergency level all industrial activities and auto usage stop.
label: air pollution alert
editorial note: JK-checked.

definition: The main rotor arc in feet and inches (meters). Used for planning helispot clearance.
label: rotor diameter

definition: Visual remains at a fire scene revealing the fire's progress and action.
label: indicator

definition: Repeat burning of an area over which a fire has previously passed, but left fuel that later ignites when burning conditions are more favorable.
label: reburn (leftover fuel)

definition: The failure of a closed container as a result of overpressurization caused by an external heat source.
label: Boiling Liquid Expanding Vapor Explosion (failure)

definition: A discrete area within a larger prescribed or fire use project.
label: burn block

definition: A numerical index related to the ability of the atmosphere to disperse smoke. Different agencies use different scales [e.g., in South Carolina, the current scale is based on ventilation factor and ranges from 1 (poor) to 5 (excellent)].
label: category day

definition: A season when weather, fire danger, and number and distribution of fires are about average.
label: normal fire season (average)

definition: The starting date, hour, and minute of the first suppression work on a fire.
label: attack time

definition: Process by which heat is imparted from one body to another, through conduction, convection, and radiation.
label: heat transfer

definition: Distance equal to the wingspread of the airtanker being used; used for corrections right or left of the flight path.
label: span

definition: The alternative that achieves incident objectives, consistent with priority for firefighter and public safety, and is least expensive when considering expected costs for fire suppression and emergency stabilization and/or rehabilitation.
label: minimum cost suppression alternative

definition: A device that computes the probable rate of spread of a fire for different combinations of fuel moisture, wind speed, and other selected factors.
label: rate of spread meter

definition: Fire pattern indicators that are generally only visible when viewed within close proximity.
label: microscale fire pattern indicator
definition extension: This may include standing nearby, and/or the need to crouch or get down on hands and knees to observe.

definition: Electronic sensor used to record the number of lightning strokes within a predetermined range over a specified period of time.
label: lightning stroke counter

definition: Administrative entity that provides resources in response to the incident.
label: responding unit

definition: A radio transmitter attached to the aircraft structure which operates from its own power source on 121.5 MHz and 243 MHz. The transmitter transmits a distinctive downward swept audio tone for homing purposes and is designed to function without human action after an accident.
label: Emergency Locator Transmitter

definition: Naturally or artificially ventilated structure, constructed to specifications and used to shield weather measuring instruments from direct sunshine and precipitation.
label: instrument shelter

definition: An unburned area within a fire perimeter.
label: island

definition: The symbol of the Cooperative Forest Fire Prevention Program since 1945. Smokey's image is protected by US Federal Law and is administered by the USDA Forest Service, the National Association of State Foresters and the Ad Council.
label: Smokey Bear

definition: Rain that freezes upon contact with objects on the ground.
label: freezing rain

definition: A wildland fire that is controlled by a strong consistent wind.
label: wind-driven wildland fire

definition: Any written agreement giving one party a right, a service, or a commodity in exchange for a right, a service, or a commodity. Contracts include land use permits, purchase orders, equipment rental agreements, leases, etc.
label: contract

definition: Fog which extends vertically to less than 20 feet.
label: ground fog

definition: Method of burning in which fires are set along the edges of an area and allowed to spread inward.
label: edge firing

definition: All supervisory positions described in the Incident Command System.
label: incident overhead

definition: A motor-driven vehicle, or group of vehicles, designed and constructed for the purpose of fighting fires. May be of different types such as engines, water tenders, ladder trucks, etc.
label: apparatus

definition: The relative amount of time a fire burns in the flaming phase of combustion, as compared to smoldering combustion. A ratio of the amount of fuel that is consumed in flaming combustion compared to the amount of fuel consumed during the smoldering phase, in which more of the fuel material is emitted as smoke particles because it is not turned into carbon dioxide and water.
label: combustion efficiency

definition: Used in some localities to specify fire set to spread against the wind in prescribed burning.
label: backburn

definition: The speed of an aircraft as shown on its pitot static airspeed indicator. Calibrated to reflect standard atmosphere adiabatic compressible flow at sea level, uncorrected for airspeed system errors.
label: Indicated Airspeed

definition: Deploying and directing resources on an incident to accomplish the objectives designated by strategy.
label: tactics

definition: The leading edge of an expanding air mass.
label: shock wave

definition: Effect of wind on smoke, retardant drops, paracargo, smokejumper streamers, etc.
label: drift

definition: The dropping of fire retardants or suppressants from specially designed buckets slung below a helicopter.
label: bucket drops

definition: The adjective classification of the sky when 5/10 or less of the sky is obscured by clouds.
label: sunny
definition extension: Part of the National Fire Danger Rating System (NFDRS).

definition: Any ground vehicle with personnel capable of maintenance, minor repairs, and limited fueling of dozers.
label: dozer tender

definition: An organization from which resources are ordered, mobilized or assigned to an incident and/or demobilized. The center may process requests, coordinate response, or track resources and information under the delegation of its benefiting agency(s).
label: dispatch center

definition: A small ridge which extends finger-like from a main ridge.
label: spur ridge

definition: Management of wildfire or prescribed fire to meet resource objectives specified in land/resource management plans.
label: use of wildland fire

definition: Ignition of fuels by dropping incendiary devices or materials from aircraft.
label: aerial ignition

definition: Aircraft with pilot used to make trial runs over the target area to check wind, smoke conditions, topography and to lead airtankers to targets and supervise their drops.
label: leadplane

definition: A defined behavior, action, process, or equipment type, agreed upon by the National Wildfire Coordinating Group for wildland fire performance, and is necessary to meet consistent, interagency fire management activities.
label: NWCG Standard

definition: The location of initial attack forces.
label: base (initial attack)

definition: A stationary in-flight condition for helicopters when no directional flight is achieved.
label: hover

definition: Uniformity and size of bubbles.
label: consistency (foam)

definition: A condition when the prevailing visibility is less than 3 miles (5 km) and rapidly increases and decreases by one or more reportable values during the period of observation.
label: variable visibility

definition: A valve with a gate-like disk that moves up and down at right angles to the flow when actuated by a stem screw and hand wheel. Gate valves are best for service that requires infrequent valve operation and where the disk is kept either fully open or closed.
label: gate valve

definition: The ratio between the amount of vertical rise of a slope and horizontal distance as expressed in a percent. One hundred feet of rise to 100 feet of horizontal distance equals 100 percent.
label: slope percent

definition: A procedural guide which describes fire meteorological services provided within the Geographic Area of responsibility, including the National Interagency Fire Center. The guide is based on the National Interagency Agreement and applicable Geographic Area Memorandum of Agreement.

definition: The systematic application of methods, procedures, and techniques common to the field of wildand fire investigation as regularly applied to solve the problems of the investigation within each specifc scene's conditions and needs.

definition: A land area definable by specified management objectives, constraints, topographic features, access, values to be protected, political boundaries, fuel types, major fire regime groups, and other defined elements that set it apart from an adjacent area. A fire management unit may have dominant management objectives and pre-selected strategies assigned to accomplish these objectives.
label: Fire Management Unit

definition: Large, portable tank from which helitankers can hoverfill.
label: fill tank

definition: The act of directing, and/or controlling resources by virtue of explicit legal, agency, or delegated authority.
label: command

definition: As it refers to atmospheric pressure, a decrease in the central pressure of a low. This is usually accompanied by intensification of the cyclonic circulation (counter-clockwise wind flow around the low).
label: deepening

definition: A pyrotechnic device specifically designed to initiate burning of a fuel mixture or propellant.
label: igniter

definition: Any vehicle capable of supplying engine fuel to ground or airborne equipment.
label: fuel tender

definition: Trough, Trough Aloft, Upper Level [Cold] Low: An elongated area of relatively low pressure, at constant altitude, in the atmosphere. The opposite of an upper level ridge. Upper level troughs are usually oriented north-south with the north end open. That is, air currents moving from west to east around the earth flow around three sides of the trough then turn eastward rather than toward the west, as in the case of a closed circulation. A large upper level trough may have one or more small upper level closed low circulation systems within it.
label: upper level (cold) trough
alternative label: trough aloft, upper level [cold] low, trough

definition: Pump which expels water by centrifugal force through the ports of a circular impeller rotating at high speed. With this type of pump, the discharge line may be shut off while the pump is running without damaging the pump or hose.
label: centrifugal pump

definition: How high above the level of release an emission plume rises.
label: plume rise

definition: Any method or pattern of igniting a wildland area to consume the fuel in a prescribed pattern. E.g., heading or backing fire, spot fire, strip-head fire, and ring fire.
label: firing technique

definition: Manner in which a prescribed fire is ignited. The distance between ignition lines or points and the sequence of igniting them is determined by weather, fuel, topography, firing technique, and other factors which influence fire behavior and fire effects.
label: ignition pattern

definition: A major failure of a closed liquid container into two or more pieces when the temperature of the liquid is well above its boiling point at normal atmospheric pressure.
label: Boiling Liquid Expanding Vapor Explosion (major failure)

definition: Luminous oxidation of gases evolved from the rapid decomposition of fuel. Relatively efficient combustion produces minimal soot and tar, resulting in white smoke; high moisture content also produces white smoke.
label: flaming combustion phase

definition: A set of mathematical equations that can be used to predict certain aspects of fire behavior when provided with an assessment of fuel and environmental conditions.
label: fire behavior prediction model

definition: The value specified by the manufacturer as the maximum allowable weight placed on an axle of a vehicle when fully equipped, including payload, fluids and occupants.
label: Gross Axle Weight Rating

definition: A number related to the potential of firebrands to which a given area will be exposed during the rating day.
label: risk (fire danger)
definition extension: Part of the National Fire Danger Rating System (NFDRS).

definition: An inversion caused by subsiding air, often resulting in decreased atmospheric mixing conditions.
label: subsidence inversion

definition: The first combustible material ignited beyond the components of the ignition source itself.
label: first fuel ignited

definition: An area that may be adversely affected by smoke from a prescribed burn.
label: smoke target

definition: Spinning vortex column of ascending hot air and gases rising from a fire and carrying aloft smoke, debris, and flame. Fire whirls range in size from less than one foot to over 500 feet in diameter. Large fire whirls have the intensity of a small tornado.
label: fire whirl

definition: Indicates that the airtanker has the target in sight and will make a retardant drop on this run over the target.
label: drop pass

definition: A separate radio frequency most commonly used in air traffic control which reduces frequency congestion by controlling the number of aircraft or other resources operating on a particular frequency.
label: discrete frequency

definition: The process by which a gas becomes a liquid.
label: condensation

definition: A card issued to persons showing their incident management and trainee qualifications to fill specified fire management positions in an incident management organization.
label: incident qualifications card

definition: The designation of a vegetation complex described by dominant species, age, and form.
label: cover type

definition: A partitioned wall placed in vehicular or aircraft water tanks to reduce shifting of the water load when starting, stopping or turning.
label: baffle

definition: Odd or "even" thousand-foot (305 m) altitudes or flight levels. E.g., 5,000, 6,000, 7,000; FL 250, FL 260, and FL 270.
label: cardinal altitudes

definition: Functional unit within the planning section responsible for collecting, recording and safeguarding all documents relevant to the incident.
label: Documentation Unit

definition: Treatment of slash to reduce fire hazard or for other purposes. Preferred to "brush disposal."
label: slash disposal

definition: Process during which oxygen combines with another substance.
label: oxidation

definition: A mobile weather data collection and forecasting system consisting of a communications module, weather observing module, and data interigation module. Used by incident meteorologists on an incident.
label: All Hazards Meteorological Response System

definition: Coupling made to receive a male coupling of the same thread, pitch and/or diameter.
label: female coupling

definition: The visible or measurable physical changes formed by a fire effect or group of fire effects. This can be over a small area or it can include the overall pattern of fire spread as determined by the entirety of fire pattern indicators over a larger area.
label: fire pattern

definition: Mathematical or quantitative representation or simulation of air quality processes; e.g., emission models, receptor models, or air quality dispersion models.
label: air quality model

definition: Wind created by differing barometric pressures between high- and low-pressure systems. Velocity is generally five to 30 miles per hour, and wind shifts are usually gradual as systems move and shift.
label: gradient wind (weather system)

definition: Fire set between main fire and backfire to hasten spread of backfire.
label: counter fire (hasten spread)

definition: Aircraft operating in accordance with clearances within control zones in weather conditions less than the basic Visual Flight Rules weather minima.
label: Special Visual Flight Rules

definition: According to the American Meteorological Society, the average temperature of the air as indicated by a properly exposed thermometer during a given time period, usually a day, a month, or a year.
label: average temperature

definition: The amount of a specified fuel type or strata that is removed through the fire process, often expressed as a percentage of the preburn weight.
label: consumption

definition: Historically, the average number of human-caused fires occurring on a protection unit per month during the established fire season.
label: seasonal monthly average

definition: The area where investigator(s) begin their on-scene search for the general origin area.
label: initial investigative area
definition extension: Usually an area of advancing fire.

definition: The greatest 5-second average wind speed during the previous hour that exceeded 25 knots.
label: peak wind

definition: The heat energy resulting from the complete combustion of a fuel, expressed as the quantity of heat per unit weight of fuel. The high heat of combustion is the potential available, and the low heat of combustion is the high heat of combustion minus several losses that occur in an open system (primarily heat of vaporization of moisture in the fuel).
label: heat of combustion

definition: Any ground vehicle capable of transporting a dozer, tractor, or other heavy piece of equipment.
label: heavy equipment transport

definition: Term used as a title for subordinates of the command staff positions. In some cases, assistants are also assigned to unit leader positions in the planning, logistics, and finance/administration sections. Qualifications, technical capability, and responsibility of assistants are normally less than those of the person holding the primary position.
label: assistant

definition: A fire department company or a response unit, the members of which are not paid.
label: volunteer fire company

definition: The specific dimensions of screw thread employed to coupled fire hose and equipment. American National Standards (NH) have been adopted for fire hose couplings threads in 3/4, 1-1/2, 2-1/2, 3-1/2, 4, 5, and 6-inch sizes.
label: hose thread

definition: Insignificant change in wind speed, direction, and temperature (less than 5 degrees) and relative humidity (less than five percent), respectively. When used as a general statement in a long-range forecast, all four criteria apply.
label: little change

definition: Mobile medical treatment and transportation.
label: medivac

definition: Any changing characteristic; in statistics, a measurable characteristic of an experimental unit.
label: variable

definition: Actions that are implemented to reduce or eliminate (mitigate) risks to persons, property or natural resources. These actions can be undertaken before and during a wildfire. Before a fire actions can include fuel treatments, creation of fuel breaks or barriers around critical or sensitive sites or resources, and vegetation modification and structural changes to increase the chance a structure will survive a wildfire with or without active protection (sometimes referred to as defensible space or the home ignition zone). Mitigation actions can also occur during response and can include mechanical and physical tasks, specific fire applications, and limited suppression actions. Such as fireline construction, and creating "black lines" through the use of controlled burnouts to limit fire spread and behavior.
label: mitigation actions

definition: The most common type of hose attached and stored on wildland engine booster reels. The hose is made of neoprene and does not appreciably collapse when stored empty.
label: booster hose

definition: Any excess personal property not required for the needs and the discharge of the responsibilities of all federal agencies as determined by the General Services Administration (GSA).
label: surplus property

definition: As specialized in meteorology, atmospheric motions that are predominantly vertical in the absence of wind (which distinguishes this process from advection), resulting in vertical transport and mixing of atmospheric properties.
label: convection (meteorology)

definition: Rapid advance of the head of a fire, characterized by a marked transition in fireline intensity and rate of spread with respect to that noted before and after the advance.
label: run (of a fire)

definition: The working environment within the influence of a particular leader or chain of command. The command climate is based on the subordinates' understanding of how they are expected to perform, how they are treated, and how they must conform to the leader's style.
label: command climate

definition: A number that indicates the relative net effects of daily fire danger on the fire load for an area during a specified period, such as a fire season.
label: severity index

definition: Nautical miles per hour, equal to 1.15 mph.
label: knot

definition: The long narrow extensions of a fire projecting from the main body.
label: fingers of a fire

definition: A proportioning method or device that requires a manual adjustment to maintain a desired mix ratio over a changing range of water flows and pressures.
label: manually regulated

definition: A line connecting points of equal atmospheric pressure on a weather map.
label: isobar

definition: An 8-character identifier assigned by NESDIS that becomes the RAWS identification number for use with the GOES satellite.
label: NESDIS ID

definition: A hose-coupling device having two male thread nipples for connecting hose and for connecting two female couplings of the same diameter.
label: double male coupling

definition: All personnel and equipment available or potentially available for assignment to incidents.
label: fire resources

definition: Emergency care or treatment given to an ill or injured person before regular medical care can be obtained. First aid is generally provided by someone other than a physician. On incidents, most first aid is provided in the field or camp by medical unit personnel such as Emergency Medical Technicians (EMT).
label: first aid

definition: In meteorology, the boundary between two air masses of differing atmospheric properties.
label: front

definition: The use of fire to accomplish a specified objective.
label: fire treatment

definition: Geographical position determined by visual reference to the surface, by reference to one or more radio navigational aids, by celestial plotting, or by any other navigational device.
label: fix

definition: An individual designated by the Contracting Officer to provide technical support for the contract within specific authority and limitations as specified in the delegation. The COTR/COR must be agency certified.
label: Contracting Officers Technical Representative

definition: Any soil or soil horizon containing at least 30% organic matter (e.g., muck, peat).
label: organic soil

definition: The probable moisture content of fast-drying fuels which have a timelag constant of 1 hour or less; such as, grass, leaves, ferns, tree moss, pine needles, and small twigs (0-1/4").
label: fine fuel moisture

definition: A method of lighting prescribed fires where ignition points are set individually at a predetermined spacing and with predetermined timing throughout the area to be burned.
label: spot fire technique

definition: A two-character code to describe each measurement taken at a weather station.
label: Standard Hydrologic Exchange Format code

definition: An ignition device suspended under a helicopter, capable of dispensing ignited fuel to the ground for assistance in burning out or backfiring.
label: aerial torch

definition: Creating a seal with foam which prevents a release of flammable vapors from fuels.
label: vapor suppression

definition: Points on the cumulative distribution of one fire weather/fire danger index without regard to associated fire occurrence/business.
label: climatological breakpoint

definition: A smoke emission control strategy that considers meteorological conditions when scheduling prescribed fires in order to avoid incursions into smoke sensitive areas.
label: avoidance

definition: Dropping by an airtanker of its entire load of fire retardant at one time.
label: salvo

definition: A common VHF-FM frequency used by natural resource agency aircraft for emergency radio transmissions.
label: air guard

definition: Quantity of heat or electrical energy that must be absorbed by a substance to ignite and burn.
label: ignition energy

definition: Reduction of fire hazard in rough, usually by prescribed burning.
label: rough reduction

definition: Term used in flight planning/following to document actual time spent flying between points.
label: Actual Time En Route

definition: Assistance in firefighting or investigation by fire agencies, without regard for jurisdictional boundaries.
label: mutual aid

definition: Any area where lack of flammable material obstructs the spread of wildfires.
label: natural barrier

definition: A simple role-play simulation technique that challenges participants to make decisions and communicate those decisions to others. A tactical decision game is an experiential learning method that is tactical in nature and has time and information constraints to put participants under some level of stress.
label: Tactical Decision Game

definition: Developed or undeveloped area that has been tested and will accommodate STOL aircraft.
label: Short Takeoff or Landing Airstrip

definition: The increase in strength of a fire management organization.
label: build-up (fire management)
editorial note: JK-checked.  FDS and FWS also listed in NWCG, but not shown.

definition: The actual rate of decrease of temperature with elevation.
label: environmental lapse rate

definition: Passage of liquid through a porous body, as movement of water through soil.
label: percolation

definition: The speed and intensity of actions relative to the speed and intensity of the unfolding events in the operational environment.
label: operational tempo

definition: Model legislation, recommended by the Fire Marshals' Association of North America and adopted in most states, dealing with the subject of arson.
label: Model Arson Law

definition: A collective term that refers to stands of vegetation dominated by shrubby, woody plants, or low growing trees, usually of a type undesirable for livestock or timber management.
label: brush

definition: Chemical that, when applied to a living plant, causes or accelerates drying of its aerial parts; used to facilitate burning of living vegetation by substantially lowering fuel moisture content within a few hours.
label: desiccant

definition: General term for two or more firefighters organized to work as a unit.
label: fire crew

definition: The response of one attack unit to a fire or other emergency with no regard for the number of return trips to that same fire or emergency.
label: attack unit response

definition: Computerized interagency summary of fire suppression qualifications of listed personnel. Available information includes fire training record, fire experience record, and physical fitness testing score for each individual.

definition: A continuous, five-step process that provides a systematic method for identifying and managing the risks associated with any operation.

definition: To reduce the flame or heat on the more vigorously burning parts of a fire edge.
label: knock down

definition: The location of the communications unit and the message center.
label: Incident Communications Center

definition: Values of one or more fire weather/fire danger indexes that have been statistically related to occurrence of fires (fire business). Generally the threshold is a value, or range of values where historical fire activity has significantly increased or decreased.
label: fire business thresholds

definition: All activities for the management of wildland fires to meet land management objectives. label: fire management

definition: All actions taken to stop the spread of fire.
label: holding actions

definition: A group of trained firefighters stationed at a dispatch point for quick, rapid deployment.
label: stand-by crew

definition: A tank, a live hose reel or tray, an auxiliary pump, and an engine combined into a single one-piece assembly which can be slipped onto a truck bed or trailer.
label: slip-on tanker

definition: Simulated fuel complex for which all fuel descriptors required for the solution of a mathematical rate of spread model have been specified.
label: fuel model

definition: Any area wherein residences and other developments are scattered and intermingled with forest, range, or farm land and native vegetation or cultivated crops.
label: rural

definition: A line of water, or water and chemical retardant, sprayed along the ground, and which serves as a temporary control line from which to ignite or stop a low-intensity fire.
label: wet line

definition: A device employed to allow a firesetter the opportunity to leave the scene prior to the ignition of the fire.
label: time delay device

definition: Method of carrying hose on the shoulders.
label: shoulder carry

definition: The dispatch center associated with a resource’s home unit. The Home Dispatch Center is responsible for initial mobilization and is the Center associated with the resource when an assignment is completed.
